story:
UPDATE: 03/08/2014

Our blog is now online, so once you're done here, come visit us at:

http://jigsolian.com/blog/


Help Me Put a Value-Based Game Online

Hi.  My name is Eric Beste.  I am a scenario writer and game designer with a mission to make the online games business fair for the players that make it a multi-billion-dollar, global industry.  So, this project will be an ultra-mass-scale game that:

  • increases the value of competing for the players
  • creates opportunities for students to pay some of their education bills
  • promotes literacy across income levels
  • demonstrates the benefits of a Sharing Culture

A value-based game (VBG) is a competition that allows players a method to both appropriately and fairly share the revenues generated by the game.

I've created a VBG called the Mass Tournament Project.  It turns online game playing into the mind sport that it is; and it will pay winners (1 out of every 15 players) for their efforts.

It's only fair.  Online games playing is the new 21st century lifestyle.  We practice and compete in them every day -- spending billions of dollars each year to do so.  If physical athletes earn money (not trinkets or avatars) competing in their sports, players of mind sports should, too.  And they will when I launch my game.



Pledge Now So We Can 'Get It Done' Quicker

The beautiful virtual box top above was designed by Steve Gertz, one of the designers in our early prototype stage.  The final art you see above is by Kimberly Brink, who is not only a wonderful artist, but a great singer, public speaker, and scientist as well.  They are part of an extensive team of volunteers who have contributed thousands of hours to the game that will make online games fair for everyone.

Unfortunately, the launch phase adds layers of complexities and costs that require us to raise funds to get the system working online for the world to enjoy.

So, we've teamed with the brilliant programming group at iWerk in Royal Oak, Michigan.  Their expertise will allow us to launch the initial cross-platform elements of the project.

Our goal is to launch before this summer (2014).  So you won't have to wait long to see the results of your generosity.  Pledge now to help us unveil the project sooner.

Pledgers of the Mass Tournament Project

You're going to love what we have in store for you.

  • You get to play in the Alpha Tests before the launch
  • You'll have full membership privileges for up to a full year (see Perks)
  • You get updates on our launch progress in our blog (coming soon)
  • Some of you will even get invites to our Launch Party

Funding will help pay for launch coding, materials and shipping for perks, modest pay for team members contributing to the launch (artists, musicians, etc); and to pay any required taxes.

BONUS.  If we should be fortunate enough to raise double the amount we're seeking, we will set up a full month of special tournaments that will be reserved for pledgers.

About the Game

The Mass Tournament Project (MTP) is a multi-layered game system that I designed.  It is the world's first true mass tournament system.  It is unique because it:
  • allows ultra-mass scale competition
  • engages all competitors at the same task at the same time
  • requires very little bandwidth
  • is an original design; created specifically for mass tournament play

A single tournament can accommodate any number of players; and 1-in-15 players will always earn a prize that is at least equal to their entry fee (1-in 10 when a tournament's volume is really high).

Practice play is free for all.  Members will have unlimited practice play.  All pledgers will have membership privileges (see Perks).

$2,000 Minimum Top Prize Guarantees

Two of the four tournaments starting at the launch will offer members guaranteed minimum top prizes.  They are the Daily MTP and the College Open Tourneys (COTs).  Visitors (non-members) will also enjoy large top prizes if they win, just not at much as members.  (See "The MTP Game" below.)

Why members?  Membership fees will allow our team to operate the system more consistently.  They will also be the primary source for the top prize guarantees.

The MTP Game

The MTP Game is a word game designed specifically for mass tournament play.  It uses hexagonal tiles (as shown below) to allow players to make words in any direction.

Players will be able to select letter sets in both 2D or 3D formats.  A variety of sets will be available -- even black-and-white -- to let each player choose their favorites for practice play.

A Game That Everyone Can Play

One of the great things about word games is that they have almost universal appeal.  That's why we chose the word-game genre as the first in our series.

More than 100 million people play word games every week in English alone.  And you don't have to be in love with word games to benefit from the system.  Players of all levels of competency will earn money from the system.  So, you might even use what you earn to play games that you might like more.

Level One: The Launch

There are more than 50 levels to the MTP game.  At the launch, we'll be releasing Level One for all practice play and tournament applications.  Within six months after the launch, five-to-ten additional levels will be coded in for your enjoyment.

As well, the initial game will be in English (with words common to US, UK, Canada, India, and Australia).  As funds allow, we will add additional languages to the system.  And the dictionaries will constantly be updated.

There are more than a trillion field solutions in Level One alone, so you'll always be exposed to great challenges when you play.

The illustration below contains thumbnails of a few of the many thousands of Level One challenges I've completed during the design process.


The MTP Tournaments: Making History

 When you pledge, you will become part of online games history.  You will be among the people helping to make online games fair, not only for businesses but for players as well.

Here are a few of the VBG Rules that help to make the MTP game fair to all players:

  • competitive -- the game must be challenging to the competitor
  • fair -- players must engage in the same task at the same time
  • diverse -- the system must separate players according to ability
  • not gambling -- success must be based on player effort, not chance
  • non-trivial prizes -- player earnings no less than contest entry fee

The MTP meets and exceeds all of the basic VBG criteria as defined above.  One out of every fifteen players will earn money from participating in each of the MTP tournaments.

The Launch Tournaments

The launch version of the MTP will include individual practice play and massively scalable tournament play as follows:

  • FREE online practice play -- unlimited to members; monthly limit to others
  • Beginners Tournament -- occurring multiple times per day; high-level players not allowed
  • Challenger Tournament -- occurs multiple times per day; more difficult than Beginners Tournament
  • The College Open Tourney (COT) -- weekly event open to COT members only; must be 16-29 years old (intended for college and high school students); more difficult than Beginners Tournament; guaranteed min. top prize of $2,000 US
  • The Daily MTP -- occurs once daily in each the PST and EST time zones; this is the first of the official tournaments that will lead to the annual championship contest; more difficult than Beginners Tournament; guaranteed minimum top prize of $2,000 US

And there's a lot more.  So Pledge Now.

We've spent an awful lot of time designing a system with benefits for players who love to play casual games.  Here's a little peek at some of the features we'll be adding after the launch:

  • the OPM-1 virtual player module will allow you to enjoy one-on-one play with your favorite adversary in the system
  • schools will be able to form teams to compete against other clubs or schools
  • members will be able to organize custom tournaments with family and friends for holiday play
  • charities will be able to organize large-scale events online for critical fundraising
  • businesses will be able to sponsor events and/or organize custom events to promote their brands

The MTP is a true 21st century game.  Your pledge will make it happen.

Spread the Word!

Send your friends and colleagues on Facebook and Twitter this page link so they can be a part of online games history, too.

The Indiegogo share tools make it easy for you to share with your friends, so please use them and let the world know about us.

Welcome to the Sharing Revolution.  Thank you for giving us a chance to make online games fair for everyone.  It's time for us players to benefit from the industry we've built.

THIS IS THE FUTURE OF THE ONLINE GAMES INDUSTRY.  COME SEE US AGAIN SOON.  WE WILL BE UPDATING YOU ON OUR PROGRESS.

CHECK OUT OUR BLOG AT: http://jigsolian.com/blog/

story:
It's time for the world to have a Museum of Dungeons & Dragons. This page asks for your support for it, but there is much that you will get for your donation:

  • First, and most importantly to us, YOU the supporters will get to choose the location of the museum. In fact, it is important enough to us that we aren't using Kickstarter simply because they required us to choose a location before they would approve us
  • Second, the story of the game will be told in a way that will be interesting for you whether you played a few times in college two decades ago, or you've played every week since the game came out in the 1970's.
  • Third, we will preserve all parts of the game - from rare unpublished manuscripts, to the module that everyone remembers playing.

 

THE THOUGHTS BEHIND THE MUSEUM:

For many years, we’ve been thinking about all of the collections that just get thrown out or given away to people who don't know what they are. We personally saw a pile of D&D books destroyed by a local charitable organization. I'm sure the person who donated them didn't want that, and the entire idea of books being destroyed makes us cringe. 

Also, we have a large collection personally (which will be the founding collection for the museum). We have no children, so have considered what will happen to our library when we pass away. We contacted the Smithsonian, who told us they would accept the collection, but it would most likely be stored away and not displayed. We heard of a university in Texas (I believe) that had a gaming collection, but in contacting them, we learned that it was not available to the general public, only university students and staff. So we were left wondering what to do.

Then E. Gary Gygax passed away, and parts of his collection were sold. A lot of people said, "These should be in a museum." But no one made any steps towards creating that museum.

Then Dave Arneson passed away, and there was a storage shed of his gaming stuff that was sold off at an auction like you see on Storage Wars. Parts of it ended up on eBay, but we don't know what happened to the rest of it. Again, everyone said, "These items need to be preserved," but no one did anything.

So the idea of creating a permanent museum that has been in the process in our brains jumped forward, and demanded to be done now. The founders of this game and the original gamers are aging, and more and more collections like this will be destroyed if something isn't done soon. 

Getting across our passion for the game online isn't easy. Maybe the best way to describe it is the way we explain it at conventions: we consider ourselves paladins of Dungeons & Dragons. Rather like Varys from Game of Thrones is a champion of the kingdom - no matter who sits on the throne, the kingdom must survive. 

Without the contributions of Gary and Dave, the world would be a different place. They created the concept of fantasy roleplaying games. Without them, we'd all be playing wargames. Video games wouldn't exist in their current form (although video wargames may have been developed). 

 

PLANS:

We will be opening the museum’s new location in 2014 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the release of Dungeons & Dragons. The timing will be tight, as we have to find the right place to house the museum in a permanent resting place, build it out (i.e. put in necessary walls and ceilings), then design and build all of the museum's displays. But plans are in place to get it done, and you will be kept updated every step of the way! 

We have spent a lot of time planning over the past few years, including locations. We have decided to let you, our supporters, choose where the museum should be located. Once we fund, we will send an email to everyone on our mailing list with a link to a survey, so you can vote on where we will be opening (Yes, we're willing to move to the other end of the country if that's where you want the museum to be - we are THAT dedicated to this cause!). There are four locations that we consider appropriate to the game: 

 
 
LOCATIONS:  
1A. Lake Geneva, WI Where it all started, and where many of the artists and game designers who worked for TSR still reside. This area is rich with D&D gaming history. Also, it is fairly centrally located in the US
 
1B. Orlando, FL Dave Arneson taught game design in this area for many years. In addition, it is an area where most people will travel at least once in their lives (Disney World is located there, after all). It would be the most likely to allow international fans of D&D to visit the museum.
 
2A. Indianapolis, IN Where GenCon (where D&D became a smash hit) is currently being held. Tens of thousands of gaming fans flock to this area every summer.
 
2B. Renton, WA Where Wizards of the Coast, the publisher of Dungeons & Dragons since 1997, is headquartered. 
 
 

FUTURE PLANS:

One of the missions of the museum will be to spread knowledge of the history of the game to as many people as possible. This will be done, in part, through traveling displays at as many conventions throughout the country as possible. (For instance, we know MANY gamers who started playing in 2000, and have never held a copy of the older products, or looked through them to see if there are ideas in them that they can bring to their current game. Likewise, gamers who stopped moving to new editions at some point might gain ideas from new products.) 

The museum's first planned expansion will include related/licensed products like Judge's Guild and the D20 products. Future plans include adding wings to the museum for other RPGs. We hope to do three different sections - science fiction, fantasy, and horror. These would include both older and current games.  

 

REWARDS:

And now on to the fun things... the rewards! We know that you're curious about what you'll get, so below are pictures of the items we're giving you as a thank you: 

Book (note that ALL of the backers will be listed in the book, so if you want to see your name in print, this is your chance!):

Tote bag and t-shirt:

Convention tickets - it's hard to show pictures that give a good feel about these, so below are links to their pages, in chronological order:

  • Winter Fantasy: http://www.baldmangames.com/
  • Gary Con: http://www.garycon.com/
  • GenCon: http://www.gencon.com/

The artwork shown below is copyright their respective artists, and is used with permission:

Elmore, Basic and Expert Box Sets, Basic D&D:

Easley, Player's Handbook and Dungeon Master's Guide, 2nd Edition:

Lockwood, Sunless Citadel and Forge of Fury modules, 3rd Edition:

All art will be signed with a note thanking you for supporting the museum.

 

FOR MORE INFORMATION:

Check out the museum's facebook page and blog. There are so many details that it would be impossible to put them all here. We've been trying to post as many of our thoughts and plans as we can.

Third, we will preserve all parts of the game - from rare unpublished manuscripts, to the module that everyone remembers playing.

We personally saw a pile of D&D books destroyed by a local charitable organization. I'm sure the person who donated them didn't want that, and the entire idea of books being destroyed makes us cringe. 
Also, we have a large collection personally (which will be the founding collection for the museum). We have no children, so have considered what will happen to our library when we pass away. We contacted the Smithsonian, who told us they would accept the collection, but it would most likely be stored away and not displayed. We heard of a university in Texas (I believe) that had a gaming collection, but in contacting them, we learned that it was not available to the general public, only university students and staff. So we were left wondering what to do.
Then E. Gary Gygax passed away, and parts of his collection were sold. A lot of people said, "These should be in a museum." But no one made any steps towards creating that museum.
Then Dave Arneson passed away, and there was a storage shed of his gaming stuff that was sold off at an auction like you see on Storage Wars. Parts of it ended up on eBay, but we don't know what happened to the rest of it. Again, everyone said, "These items need to be preserved," but no one did anything.
So the idea of creating a permanent museum that has been in the process in our brains jumped forward, and demanded to be done now. The founders of this game and the original gamers are aging, and more and more collections like this will be destroyed if something isn't done soon. 
Getting across our passion for the game online isn't easy. Maybe the best way to describe it is the way we explain it at conventions: we consider ourselves paladins of Dungeons & Dragons. Rather like Varys from Game of Thrones is a champion of the kingdom - no matter who sits on the throne, the kingdom must survive. 
Without the contributions of Gary and Dave, the world would be a different place. They created the concept of fantasy roleplaying games. Without them, we'd all be playing wargames. Video games wouldn't exist in their current form (although video wargames may have been developed). 
 
PLANS:
We will be opening the museum’s new location in 2014 to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the release of Dungeons & Dragons. The timing will be tight, as we have to find the right place to house the museum in a permanent resting place, build it out (i.e. put in necessary walls and ceilings), then design and build all of the museum's displays. But plans are in place to get it done, and you will be kept updated every step of the way! 
We have spent a lot of time planning over the past few years, including locations. We have decided to let you, our supporters, choose where the museum should be located. Once we fund, we will send an email to everyone on our mailing list with a link to a survey, so you can vote on where we will be opening (Yes, we're willing to move to the other end of the country if that's where you want the museum to be - we are THAT dedicated to this cause!). There are four locations that we consider appropriate to the game: 
 

 
LOCATIONS:  
1A. Lake Geneva, WI Where it all started, and where many of the artists and game designers who worked for TSR still reside. This area is rich with D&D gaming history. Also, it is fairly centrally located in the US
 
1B. Orlando, FL Dave Arneson taught game design in this area for many years. In addition, it is an area where most people will travel at least once in their lives (Disney World is located there, after all). It would be the most likely to allow international fans of D&D to visit the museum.
 
2A. Indianapolis, IN Where GenCon (where D&D became a smash hit) is currently being held. Tens of thousands of gaming fans flock to this area every summer.
 
2B. Renton, WA Where Wizards of the Coast, the publisher of Dungeons & Dragons since 1997, is headquartered. 

 

 
FUTURE PLANS:
One of the missions of the museum will be to spread knowledge of the history of the game to as many people as possible. This will be done, in part, through traveling displays at as many conventions throughout the country as possible. (For instance, we know MANY gamers who started playing in 2000, and have never held a copy of the older products, or looked through them to see if there are ideas in them that they can bring to their current game. Likewise, gamers who stopped moving to new editions at some point might gain ideas from new products.) 
The museum's first planned expansion will include related/licensed products like Judge's Guild and the D20 products. Future plans include adding wings to the museum for other RPGs. We hope to do three different sections - science fiction, fantasy, and horror. These would include both older and current games.  
 
REWARDS:
And now on to the fun things... the rewards! We know that you're curious about what you'll get, so below are pictures of the items we're giving you as a thank you: 
Book (note that ALL of the backers will be listed in the book, so if you want to see your name in print, this is your chance!):

Tote bag and t-shirt:

Convention tickets - it's hard to show pictures that give a good feel about these, so below are links to their pages, in chronological order:

Winter Fantasy: http://www.baldmangames.com/

Gary Con: http://www.garycon.com/

GenCon: http://www.gencon.com/


The artwork shown below is copyright their respective artists, and is used with permission:
Elmore, Basic and Expert Box Sets, Basic D&D:

Easley, Player's Handbook and Dungeon Master's Guide, 2nd Edition:

Lockwood, Sunless Citadel and Forge of Fury modules, 3rd Edition:

All art will be signed with a note thanking you for supporting the museum.
 
FOR MORE INFORMATION:
Check out the museum's facebook page and blog. There are so many details that it would be impossible to put them all here. We've been trying to post as many of our thoughts and plans as we can.

story:
Full Game Details

Click here for our Game Detail page on iTabletop.com

Why We're Building This Game:

  • We love zombie survival roleplays!
  • And yet we want it to be quick and easy to jump into a game without needing a GM or a predefined group
     
  • We love the richness of tabletop RPGs!
  • And yet we want a super-quick setup time and the ease of play of a board game, while still retaining all the rich imagination and freedom to attempt any conceivable action
     
  • We love euro-style board games!
  • And yet we want a board game that plays nicely online, with built-in video chat (since most our friends don't live nearby,) and AI and animation, (something pure board games just can't do)

There Will Be Zombies satisfies all these needs. With it, you'll be able to quickly jump into a game online, with friends and new players right in front of you via video chat, immersed in gorgeous graphics, animation and sound, working cooperatively through a huge mapped world and satisfying challenges, using your imagination and smarts to do anything plausible you can think of.

And since we've already built iTabletop™, which allows our over 8,000 customers to build their own custom online tabletop RPGs, and has built-in group video chat and tools for HD graphics, music, sound effects, PDFs, player tokens, movement grids, graphical maps, and much more, we have the perfect platform ready and waiting.

This is the genesis of There Will Be Zombies.

Get Something Useful Right Now

If you look at the perks listed, one thing you get with every perk is a full, comparably-priced license to iTabletop, which you can start using right away. Use it for:

  • Creating your own online tabletop RPGs
  • Which your friends can play online with you
  • Using built-in video chat
  • And images, music, sound effects, PDFs, character sheets, dice cups, movement grids, and so much more
  • Or join other GM's games and groups
  • And start playing right away
  • Or you can simply create cool worlds to hang out with friends or family
  • And goof off, listening to music together and adding hilarious graphics
  • While you video chat

We're glad you don't have to wait for our game to be finished before getting a useful, fun, creative, and valuable reward in iTabletop.

So watch our video, get a feel for who we are, what we've done already, and what we're raising funds to create in partnership with YOU.

And please join with us in support of this amazing game.

We know you're going to love playing it, getting involved much earlier than normal customers, and getting all the extra goodies we've planned for you.

Thank you for your time!

Full Game Details

Click here for our Game Detail page on iTabletop.com

iTabletop Details

Click here for the iTableotp website. You can check out the software for free to see what it's about if you like.

** Want to Start Small and Upgrade Later? **

No problem. Throw in your $20 now, and then later, contribute again, but this time click the CONTRIBUTE NOW button, then choose "No Perk, just a contribution!" radio button.

Enter the difference between what you first contributed, and the cost of the upgraded perk you want, and submit the contribution.

Finally, just leave us a message in the comments list regarding what you want, and we'll make it just right on the back-end!
 
 
 
 
 

Acknowledgements

There Will Be Zombies™, and Welcome to Deadford Falls™ trademark Gamesabi, LLC. There Will Be Zombies game design copyright (c) 2012 Gamesabi, LLC. iTabletop™ trademark Universal Online Magic LLC. iTabletop software design copyright (c) 2008-2012 Universal Online Magic LLC.

story:
Hello Everyone the names Ryhan Stevens i am Writer, Creator, Producer of BEASTS FURY and a small indie company called Requiem Game Studios

Requiem Game Studios would love your help in bringing BEASTSFURY to the masses on PC and Game Consoles, and we thank you for your support from the bottom of our hearts.

Links to videos and pictures!


http://www.youtube.com/user/BeastsFuryGame?feature=mhee

http://www.facebook.com/beasts.fury

https://twitter.com/BeastsFury

http://www.furaffinity.net/user/beastsfurystudio/

Please be respectful.

 

GOAL #1 - $11,000- To Get the Fully playable demo out the door!


Even making the Demo with 4 fully implented playable characters and 3 stages and 1 boss battle is expensive with all your help even donating as low $1 would bring us closer to making this game come true.

 

GOAL #2 - $30,000 - Get the game out the door!

Making a game is expensive!  Between legal fees, licensing, it is going to cost a good 30k to get this out the door. On top of that, BEASTSFURY isn't finished.  We'll definitly have many new features as the time and money allow us.  We will include the things below (onlineplay, characters, story mode) if we meet the budget for it.

GOAL #3 - $40,000 - Get Onlineplay!

This one is very difficult, but if we can make this goal or more, we will do our best to deliver online play to BEASTSFURY fans around the world.

GOAL #4 - $50,000 - Get additional characters and story mode!

This goal will give us the budget needed to add a 12 characters to the game.  Some of the characters will change everything you think you know about BEASTSFURY. It will have amazing AI and include a single player story-mode experience. This will include a brand new final boss character as well.

The Impact

This game of ours, Beast's Fury, is basically a 2D fighting game that implements 3D graphics for higher effect, much like Street Fighter IV. It includes 12 playable characters, 3 of them being boss fighters, each with their own unique endings. Unlike most arcade fighters, each character has 3 different endings. How the game is played out determines which ending you receive with each character. The fighting stages will be of a wide variety, many of which have yet to be seen in any fighting game. From bustling cities to lush jungles to exotic places all across the world. The soundtrack will be made to match the theme and atmosphere of the game and each stage, all composed by sound designers hired by Okratron 5000, a sound studio introduced to me by a friend. I have both wrote the entire story and designed the characters myself.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Please to go BEASTSFURY Facebook and Twitter

also use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Solidus Gaming is a new Video Game Media/Press website. We're trying to get our feet off the ground by adding a few website upgrades and ideas to really get us going. Which is what brought us to indiegogo.com. With help from followers, Gamers, and pledges, we can really start to make our name known in the gaming world and begin out long process of being a creditable source for gamers and geeks alike to congregate and show their passions of technology and everything gaming.

We've already done our part to reach out to companies and developers in the Press aspect. Now we just need a little help from YOU!

Just to name a few, we are on the Press List for the Following Companies:

  • Capcom
  • Square-Enix
  • Wizards of the Coast
  • gPotato
  • Ubisoft
  • Activision
  • 2Dawn Games + More!

With your help, we hope to increase our list greatly and continue to bring our fans the stories and content THEY like!

Our project is simple. We're looking for backers and pledges to make our site finally whole. If we are successful, we plan to use the money to make substantial upgrades to the site to make it more appealing to the eye, and more user friendly to our audience. With your help, we can make the site to the liking of the population, and not just the hosts/admins.

Our goal, is to write reviews and host content that people really have an open opinion about. A place where they can put in their voices and be heard by a staff that sees themselves on the same level of their viewers. We are regular gamers and people just like you and don't see ourselves above you, so we don't write biased reviews about AAA titles. If we think a game, or device is terrible, we will let you know. And in return, we would like YOU, to let us know what you think as well.

If this project is successful we will be upgrading the following:

  • Website Hosting - Dedicated Servers for better reliability and stability.
  • Upgraded Forums - vBulletin for the Cleanest Forum Experience.
  • Paid Advertising - To further reach out and increase the population of the site.
  • Game Capture Device/Software - For our video reviews, Streaming & Let's Play segments.
  • Beginning the Solidus Podcast Project - Get the Podcast ball rolling with upgrades to recording devices and software.
  • Other Updates to the community such as site merchandise (Shirts, stickers, landyards etc.) for events such as NYCC.

We came to the IndieGoGo community because we saw how some of the projects on here can be TRUE Cinderella stories for some projects out there. We've seen a few turn arounds in your community and we would like to be one of them.

Most of us aren't rich or have a Gajillon dollars just to give away to funds and programs like those on IndieGoGo. But, by just being able to click a mouse, or even just talking to a friend, YOU CAN HELP!

Just Like, Tweet, +1 and Favorite this Campaign and you'll have done MORE then enough to help us out. We really do appreciate any and all the help we can get.

Thanks for your time, and for reading our project. Feel free to browse our site and enjoy the content that is currently available! [http://s.olid.us]

story:
Short Summary

  • Kyle Vasquez and Michael Sullivan have been heavily invested in the gaming community for quite awhile. Kyle is the founding director of the four paws pet pantry in Fort Collins Colorado, which is a charity organization that helps those who are incapable to get food for their pets. He's also a life long video game lover and an entrepreneur web site developer, as well as owning several website-oriented businesses and a dog grooming salon in the past.

    Michael has been a competitive gamer since the age of 12, playing and loving every console from the Xbox One to SNES. He's had a passion for the E-Sports community since day 1, and wants to take it all to the next level of professionalism for competitors of all types.  

  • Our campaign wants to bring the concept of a next-level LAN center to life. They've existed for a long time but not how we imagine it. 
    -One stop shop for gamers of all types; controllers, computer parts, games.

    -We are going to remain open for 24 hours a day, seven days a week. 

    -Tournaments have long had venue fees; we want to do away with them for all genres of game with sponsorship programs. 

    -A cool and competitive environment is important to us, so keeping the temperature heavily regulated is expected. 

    -We want to run a weekly gaming broadcast from the center to keep all of our members up to date on the E-Sports community. 

    -We will to run monthly workshops for different games and genres every month featuring a professional level player within a community. 

  • Helping to bring a compassionate global community together and do something we love, while also doing something good for the rest of the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need $85,000 to cover property expenses, computer expenses, parts, cost of opening and organizational costs. One of our goals is to make it so players would have to pay a very minute amount of money, if anything, to participate in tournaments. We believe this should be the standard competitive gaming should be held to. After our first LAN center opens we want to be featured across the country. We can't stress enough that this is the first step!

  • The Impact
  • To make E-Sports as legitimate as anything else in our society, 
  • Sponsorship of local food drives and soup kitchens. We also want to plant a tree for every certain amount of hours purchased for play in-store. 
  • If we succeed we'll begin a plan to ensure everybody can compete in their respective game in a positive and competitive environment; we also want to focus on the concept of play without pay in tournament situations. 

Risks & Challenges

Our first issues will be launching our first LAN center, and from there the difficulty only increases as we attempt to expand our concept of the perfect LAN center world wide.

  • We are determined knowledgeable people. We don't give up and we get things done. We're going to do everything we can to ensure our cause is successful.

    Other Ways You Can Help
  • Share, Share, Share! Please get the word out. The only way we'll succeed is if the E-sports community is behind us and understands our cause. 
  • Facebook, Twitter, forums, anything you can! Please-please-please help us. We love and appreciate every effort at making E-Sports gloriously mainstream. 
    Check out our twitch over at http://www.twitch.tv/worldgamingconference

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Joannah Stewart and I run an online geek and gaming magazine called All Otaku Magazine. I studied Graphic Design at Labspace Training Centre and I am self taught in HTML and CSS coding for web design. 

Our project was started at the beginning of the year purely out of the passion my team and I have for all things geek. The bi-monthly magazine covers things like technology, gaming, anime, comics, manga, Japanese culture, movies and a host of other geeky things we can get our hands on. At first the project was just a hobby, something we enjoyed doing but when we started reaching a 600 readers in three short months we realized that there was a business opportunity here. 

So we started growing our readership and promoting the magazine and it took off, we now have over 1000 dedicated readers in 6 different countries. But we have reached our limit of expansion without funding. For us to reach our full potential we are going to need to hire the right people to make this work. 

As an online Magazine our company has two main functions. The first is our obligation to our readers, to bring them the latest and most accurate news from around the globe on anime, gaming, manga, tech and all things Otaku (or as westerners like to call it “Geek”). Our second function is as an advertising platform, with potentially thousands of people visiting our webpage and social media sites daily we have the opportunity to connect buyers and sellers in a productive manner. Our ultimate goal is to encourage the growth of the anime and gaming industry in South Africa and to eventually start influencing the global market. We want to be the Danny Choo of South Africa.

We believe that the South African gaming industry has great potential, both as gamers and game developers we show a lot of promise. And with the gaming and technology industries fast becoming two of the most lucrative markets in today’s society it is easy to see why we chose them as subjects for our magazine. But for us to cover these two industries alone would be foolish as many magazines in ZA, both online and in-store, are dedicated to gaming and tech. Magazines such as NAG and PC Format,who have been around for longer and have more experience than us, may have an advantage but they do not have the corner on an up and coming market, that is why we have decided not only to report on the gaming and tech industry but also on anime, cosplaying, manga and Japanese culture.

But what is our goal for the magazine? We are looking at creating a fully interactive magazine that will allow our readers watch videos, visit links, buy products and fill out forms all from the magazine itself. Not only is this convenient for our readers but also for advertisers. It will allow them the instant satisfaction of pay per click advertising without the time limit set by such an advertising strategy. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

With your help we can achieve so much. All Otaku Magazine is looking for $45 000 USD. With a budget like this we can set up our entire business inside of a year and be running full time releasing a monthly issue rather than a bi-monthly one and even host events that would boost the South African community like gaming tournaments and conventions.

 

The first thing we would look at doing is to buy assets like computers, a camera and software:

Dell Inspiron 7520 i7-3612 = R12 000

One Graphics PC = R14 000

Scanner printer combo = R1 000

Graphic design and publishing suites = R12 000

MS Office = R2 000

Antivirus and Payroll = R3 000

Consoles for game testing = R15 000

2 writers laptops = R6 000

Network storage - Seagate 8TB Business Storage Hard Drive = R9 000

1 Modem = R 700

2 portable modems = R 800

Office supplies = R5 000

1 Smart Phone for out of office use = R3 000

Sony DCR-SR68 80GB Camcorder(for our Youtube channel) = R4 000

 

Total = R86 500

 

Then we have our once off expenses:

 

Business Registration = R3 000

Press registration = R3 000

Copyright Registration = R20 000

Legal Fees = R12 000

Initial Advertising Campaign= R6 000

Graphic consultant for initial magazine layout = R6 000

Total = R 50 000

 

We will need to have funding for the first 4 to 6 months before we can start holding our own as a business. Monthly expenses include:

 

Internet Access = R1 200

Phone Bill = R2 000

Utilities = R2 000

Bank Charges = R 500

Transport= R1 000

Stationary (Business Cards, Letter Heads, ect.) =R3 000

Crunchyroll account = R 200

Business Insurance = R8 000

Website = R 200

Service Charges = R 6 000

Personal salary = R 4 000

Misc. = R4 000

Tax = R6 000

Total = R38 100 x 6 = R228 600 (Rounding off to R230 000)

 

Making the grand total: R 387 100.00

 

However not all of these items are needed and we would be able to set up the business with a minimal amount of money. 

 

Internet Access = R1 200

Utilities = R2 000

Bank Charges = R 500

Transport= R1 000

Business Insurance = R8 000

Website = R 200

Personal salary = R 4 000

Total = R 101 400

 

Business Registration = R3 000

Legal Fees = R12 000

Initial Advertising Campaign= R6 000

Press registration = R3 000

Total = R24 000

 

Dell Inspiron 7520 i7-3612 = R12 000

One Graphics PC = R14 000

Graphic design and publishing suites = R12 000

MS Office = R2 000

Antivirus and Payroll = R3 000

Network storage - Seagate 8TB Business Storage Hard Drive = R9 000

1 Modem = R 700

Sony DCR-SR68 80GB Camcorder(for our Youtube channel) = R4 000

2 portable modems = R 800

Total = R57 500

 

Grand Total = R182 900.00

 

What You Get

But of course we are not all about making money, we are also happy to give back to those who are willing to support us. That is why we created a list of perks for you. 

 

1. Have Your Name and Photo in Our Magazine

Once this is over we will be setting up a special page in our magazine where our sponsors names and photos will appear. Just claim the perk on the left and send us your details along witha photo. 

 

2. Be an Elite Member For a Year

For those who donate $10 or more to us, you will receive a years free subscription to the magazine making you an elite member. You will have access to special areas and competitions that other readers don't. 

 

3. Limited Edition Mimiru Mouse Pad

Supporters who donate $20 or more are eligible for a custom Limited Edition Mimiru mouse pad.  

 

4. Limited Edition Mimiru T-shirt

Get a Limited Edition Mimiru t-shirt when you donate $50.

 

5. Limited Edition Mimiru Set

Get a Limited Edition Mimiru t-shirt when you donate $50.

 

6. Limited Edition Mimiru Set

Get our custom designed Limited Edition Mimiru Hoody and Wallet set when you donate $150 or more.

 

7. Advertising

For those who have something to sell any donations bigger than $500 will receive advertising to the value of their donation. 

 

The Impact

The Impact that we will have on the geek community could be huge. Our goal is not only to report on the latest happenings from around the world but also to influence and grow the industry both here in South Africa and over seas. By using gaming as a platform to boost our other subjects we can get gamers and otaku alike to recognise other subjects like comics and anime. Because we are a free publication and we cover a variety of subjects we can also attract far more readers than most other online magazines. Our plan is to keep the magazine free and make our money off of advertising, app subscriptions and speciality subscriptions that allow our readers to access specific areas on our site or to receive extra material via email. These subscriptions will be subject to things like easter eggs and competitions. This project is not only about a passion for geeky things, it is about changing the way we entertain people and about advancing digital entertainment in the form of an interactive magazine. And beyond all of the business talk it is really about connecting people and show casing the small guys and their projects when we can. We want to be able to work with both the large corporations and the small guys with ideas. 

Here is the first version of our website. As you can see we have left a lot of room for expansion for future projects. 

http://allotakumagazine.co.za/index/

I may never have worked on a project as big as this could potentially be but then nor did any of the other people who achieved great things in this world. Steve Jobs was a collage drop out who made Apple with his bare hands, Linus Torvalds created Linux as a concept because he couldn't find a product like it on the market, Mark Zuckerberg was a social reject who found a product that people wanted. All of these people had little or no experience as business owners but they had an idea, an idea that became a passion and that passion led them to greatness. Every day that I work on this project I become more passionate and more dedicated to this project and now I want to be able to involve others in my passion but to make this work we need funding. 

Any funders will have access to all areas of our site and all the perks of having a paid subscription with us. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to help us with money then there are other ways you can help. We are always looking for writers or designers to help us with our issues, you can drop us an email at info@allotakumagazine.co.za to find out what you can do for us. Otherwise go to our Facebook page and like us or share us: https://www.facebook.com/allotakumagazine

Short Summary
Hi, my name is Joannah Stewart and I run an online geek and gaming magazine called All Otaku Magazine. I studied Graphic Design at Labspace Training Centre and I am self taught in HTML and CSS coding for web design. 
Our project was started at the beginning of the year purely out of the passion my team and I have for all things geek. The bi-monthly magazine covers things like technology, gaming, anime, comics, manga, Japanese culture, movies and a host of other geeky things we can get our hands on. At first the project was just a hobby, something we enjoyed doing but when we started reaching a 600 readers in three short months we realized that there was a business opportunity here. 
So we started growing our readership and promoting the magazine and it took off, we now have over 1000 dedicated readers in 6 different countries. But we have reached our limit of expansion without funding. For us to reach our full potential we are going to need to hire the right people to make this work. 
As an online Magazine our company has two main functions. The first is our obligation to our readers, to bring them the latest and most accurate news from around the globe on anime, gaming, manga, tech and all things Otaku (or as westerners like to call it “Geek”). Our second function is as an advertising platform, with potentially thousands of people visiting our webpage and social media sites daily we have the opportunity to connect buyers and sellers in a productive manner. Our ultimate goal is to encourage the growth of the anime and gaming industry in South Africa and to eventually start influencing the global market. We want to be the Danny Choo of South Africa.

story:
OUR STORY

Through our mutual love for games and desire to create, The Legend of Lain came about. Our company, XREVGAMES, consists of three 17 year olds. In addition to struggling to find the time to make the game, we cannot keep up with the financial costs that the production has brought about. Production of the game began in April of 2012, and because we had no idea as to what we were doing at the time, getting to a consistent pace took months. Once there, our work ethic picked up, and our once seemingly mindless doodles and ideas, became reality. However as of recent, production has slowed due to our limited time to work as well as our inability to cover the costs of music, equipment, and licensing. We have used nearly all of our available resources ranging from odd jobs to holiday money and found it in our best interest to use Indiegogo as our final way of reaching these financial deadlines.


THE GAME

The Legend of Lain is an adventure/role playing game designed for iPhone and Android devices, and although the game is still in its early stages, most of it has been planned out and we are continually working hard to complete it. The user plays as Lain, a hero who is sent on a quest to retrieve the lost Stone of Elements and banish the evil from the land. Through over 10 worlds of gameplay and a nostalgic role playing fighting style, Lain must endure countless enemies, staggering puzzles, and ruthless bosses. Also included in these many beautiful worlds are several skills to level up, unique items and equipment to collect, and multiple abilities to learn.

The story begins with the old tale of our hero’s ancestor,

“Hundreds of years ago in a far away land, a single rock known as the Stone of Elements was the source of the world’s power.
Its righteousness stood for all that was good and pure in the universe. Its power gave light to every soul throughout the land.
But inevitably, evil sought to possess its power to unleash an era of tyranny.
In an attempt to attain the rock’s unmeasurable power, many years of battle raged against the dark army.
Eventually, the leader of the dark army, Tenebris, managed to obtain the rock and he used its power to create a forcefield around his  kingdom in order to build an empire.
One day, a hero arose: one who resembled what the Stone of Elements stood for. Not a single villain could touch the hero, for his luminous and untainted spirit repelled them.”
His soul was so pure and selfless that the stone’s forcefield shattered as soon as the hero’s sacred blade struck it.
With his sacred blade, the hero banished Tenebris to the dark realm beneath the Earth, where he would lay for eternity.”

Although our hero’s ancestor triumphed over the darkness that tried to take over the land, Tenebris (the antagonist of the story) managed to reopen the Dark Realm with another archaic stone that was once thought to be non-existent, and with that he was able to seize and destroy the Stone of Elements. Lain, being the descendant of the once great hero must fulfill his destiny and stop Tenebris once again.


WHY WE NEED DONATIONS

The game has been a work in progress over the past 2 years and as it advances, the costs of making it have piled up. We have already put in hundreds of dollars ourselves, and in order for to complete our dream, we need your help in getting there. We need donations in order for us to cover our in-game costs such as licenses, equipment, and the most important, music composition. Licenses cost hundreds of dollars a year and the music are looking to have produced costs over $150 per minute of song, and its crucial for us to have a wonderfully composed and original soundtrack to make the game the best it can be. In order to keep our dream alive, we need funding, and the more donations we get, the faster we can get this game finished. Your donations do not go unrewarded, we greatly appreciate every dollar donated and to those who decide to donate more, we have perk packages in place to give back to our patrons.


FROM SKETCHES TO THE GAME

(Click to enlarge)

(Click to enlarge)


SUPPORT

If you have any questions, concerns, or comments, please email us at xrevgames@gmail.com or leave a comment on the campaign page.

 Follow us on Facebook

 Follow us on Twitter


Song in the trailer: "Follow the Horizon" by Erik Kaufman

You can find more of his songs here: http://erikkaufman.newgrounds.com

story:
The Story, The Legend:

The famous zombie hunter Hill Country Roy grew tired of bar room stories about how great a shot this guy thinks he is or how this other guy thinks it'll be so easy to survive a zombie apocalypse. All you have to do is shoot the zombies they say. You see, each of these drunk men sitting in the dingy, dark bar at the edge of town has spent their whole lives shooting at big circle bulls-eye targets. They're satisfied with putting a hole in a piece of paper and hoping that hole might slow down a charging new member of the growing undead population. 

They don't know it yet, but they won't survive the first wave and not many will.

Hill Country Roy, previously unreleased photo from before the first wave.

To help combat the unrealistic satisfaction of putting a few holes in a circle, a follower and friend of Hill Country Roy, named Anthony "Meat Hook" Arroyo developed a whole new kind of target.

Meat Hook (and no, you don't want to know how he got that nickname) saw people working on their shot at the gun range who were bored, aimless and sad. He saw them hold the righteous power of a boomstick and not be able to appreciate the significance. He saw lazy shooting. He saw disrespectful shooting.  But what he saw the most was a general lack of interest in delivering the boom to the targets at the range. 

It was then that Drop Dead Targets was born!

Drop Dead Targets is a functional target design that is about to make target shooting fun again. Forget the circles, forget the paper burglars with the black mask over their face, forget it all because we all know where the real threat lies... Zombies.

First Gen Drop Dead Target

Drop Dead Targets are realistic, 3D zombie targets with a "Kill-Shot" Gore Effect (patent pending).

After Hill Country Roy spit at it. Pure destruction.

Drop Dead Targets are guaranteed to put the fun back in zombie funeral!

All raised funds will be going to:

1. Pay for Perks: You guys are awesome, so we'll take care of you.

2. Pay for initial production run of Drop Dead Targets so we can get them into stores!

Full line production costs have been identified. Materials have been sourced. National and local retailers have interest. We have a target launch date just before Halloween and we ALWAYS HIT OUR TARGETS!

The team is ready to go, we just need your help! We have set a goal for $30,000 because that will cover all of the costs to get this product to the market.

Do you have what it takes to last the first wave of the impending zombie apocalypse? No? Then you need to start training and we're here to help. The Drop Dead Targets Kickstarter Campaign is about bringing together like-minded people who enjoy target shooting but need an injection of awesome into their lives. We need red-blooded, fully prepared members of the human race to combat the undead onslaught. 

Join the team. Support great people. Save the world!

Incentives you say? Perhaps a reward for bringing your zombie hunting prowess into the mix? Yes, there are perks that come with the job.

On top of Full Gore Effect First Generation Drop Dead Targets for your target shooting enjoyment, the Official Hill Country Roy approved team gear includes:

Drop Dead Targets Bumper Sticker (3"x9")

Drop Dead Targets Limited Edition Print (22"x28")

Drop Dead Targets T-Shirt (Men's)

Drop Dead Targets T-Shirt (Women's)

Drop Dead Targets Hoodie (Men's and Women's)

About the Drop Dead Targets Team:

Anthony Arroyo - Chico, CA - Owner, visionary and product designer. Tired of shooting the same old targets at the range and looking for something to make it a little more fun, Anthony set out to create a better target. Not only would a great target shooting experience increase his overall satisfaction with his hobby, it would make the range a more fun place for teaching teens and young adults about proper gun care, shooting techniques and safety.

Hill Country Roy - The Hill Country, US - No one is quite sure what Hill Country Roy did prior to the pandemic. He survived the first wave on guts, instinct and a 12-pack of PBR. Since then he has become a global icon in the field of deanimating corpses (zombie killing). He's known worldwide for his truck, Colonel Kurtz, his pet sasquatch, Harry, and his boomstick, the Amish flyswatter. The day Chuck Norris became a zombie, a day we all remember well, was thought to be the end of Hill Country Roy. It was just the beginning, but you already knew that. 

Stock Image of Hill Country Roy demonstrating his famous zombie head tear maneuver he used to finish off Undead Ned.

Justin Noland - Houston, TX - Business development and marketing strategist. When asked about the project Justin said, "Any product that substantially increases the enjoyment of a hobby hundreds of thousands of people are involved in is a great idea. When it is a great idea and it's fun, I can't help but want to be a part. This is an opportunity for a friend of mine to do something incredible and make a living doing something he loves." Justin is a driving force behind niche brands like American Medical ID, Go Sport ID, MyIHR and more!

Drop Dead Targets on Facebook and Twitter

Please help spread the word! Use Indiegogo's share tools, post on Facebook, tell your friends, talk to your parents, but don't run down a local cop with yelling about the zombie apocalypse!

Thank you for reading, backing us and helping us launch this product, for the safety and happiness of all humankind!

To help combat the unrealistic satisfaction of putting a few holes in a circle, a follower and friend of Hill Country Roy, named Anthony "Meat Hook" Arroyo developed a whole new kind of target.
Meat Hook (and no, you don't want to know how he got that nickname) saw people working on their shot at the gun range who were bored, aimless and sad. He saw them hold the righteous power of a boomstick and not be able to appreciate the significance. He saw lazy shooting. He saw disrespectful shooting.  But what he saw the most was a general lack of interest in delivering the boom to the targets at the range. 

It was then that Drop Dead Targets was born!

Drop Dead Targets is a functional target design that is about to make target shooting fun again. Forget the circles, forget the paper burglars with the black mask over their face, forget it all because we all know where the real threat lies... Zombies.

First Gen Drop Dead Target
Drop Dead Targets are realistic, 3D zombie targets with a "Kill-Shot" Gore Effect (patent pending).

After Hill Country Roy spit at it. Pure destruction.
Drop Dead Targets are guaranteed to put the fun back in zombie funeral!
All raised funds will be going to:
1. Pay for Perks: You guys are awesome, so we'll take care of you.
2. Pay for initial production run of Drop Dead Targets so we can get them into stores!
Full line production costs have been identified. Materials have been sourced. National and local retailers have interest. We have a target launch date just before Halloween and we ALWAYS HIT OUR TARGETS!
The team is ready to go, we just need your help! We have set a goal for $30,000 because that will cover all of the costs to get this product to the market.
Do you have what it takes to last the first wave of the impending zombie apocalypse? No? Then you need to start training and we're here to help. The Drop Dead Targets Kickstarter Campaign is about bringing together like-minded people who enjoy target shooting but need an injection of awesome into their lives. We need red-blooded, fully prepared members of the human race to combat the undead onslaught. 
Join the team. Support great people. Save the world!
Incentives you say? Perhaps a reward for bringing your zombie hunting prowess into the mix? Yes, there are perks that come with the job.
On top of Full Gore Effect First Generation Drop Dead Targets for your target shooting enjoyment, the Official Hill Country Roy approved team gear includes:

Drop Dead Targets Bumper Sticker (3"x9")

Drop Dead Targets Limited Edition Print (22"x28")

Drop Dead Targets T-Shirt (Men's)

Drop Dead Targets T-Shirt (Women's)

Drop Dead Targets Hoodie (Men's and Women's)
About the Drop Dead Targets Team:
Anthony Arroyo - Chico, CA - Owner, visionary and product designer. Tired of shooting the same old targets at the range and looking for something to make it a little more fun, Anthony set out to create a better target. Not only would a great target shooting experience increase his overall satisfaction with his hobby, it would make the range a more fun place for teaching teens and young adults about proper gun care, shooting techniques and safety.
Hill Country Roy - The Hill Country, US - No one is quite sure what Hill Country Roy did prior to the pandemic. He survived the first wave on guts, instinct and a 12-pack of PBR. Since then he has become a global icon in the field of deanimating corpses (zombie killing). He's known worldwide for his truck, Colonel Kurtz, his pet sasquatch, Harry, and his boomstick, the Amish flyswatter. The day Chuck Norris became a zombie, a day we all remember well, was thought to be the end of Hill Country Roy. It was just the beginning, but you already knew that. 

Stock Image of Hill Country Roy demonstrating his famous zombie head tear maneuver he used to finish off Undead Ned.
Justin Noland - Houston, TX - Business development and marketing strategist. When asked about the project Justin said, "Any product that substantially increases the enjoyment of a hobby hundreds of thousands of people are involved in is a great idea. When it is a great idea and it's fun, I can't help but want to be a part. This is an opportunity for a friend of mine to do something incredible and make a living doing something he loves." Justin is a driving force behind niche brands like American Medical ID, Go Sport ID, MyIHR and more!
Drop Dead Targets on Facebook and Twitter
Please help spread the word! Use Indiegogo's share tools, post on Facebook, tell your friends, talk to your parents, but don't run down a local cop with yelling about the zombie apocalypse!
Thank you for reading, backing us and helping us launch this product, for the safety and happiness of all humankind!

story:
Secret Doors? Check, Deadly Traps? Check, Hidden Treasures? Check, Terrifying Monsters? Check, Slim Chance of Survival? Check.

Where Do I Sign Up?

(p.s. Don't forget your 10 foot pole.)

(p.p.s Ummm, yeah. Forget the pole, it won't really help you against THAT.)

This indiegogo campaign is designed to support the creation of Barrowmaze II (BMII) and, while doing so, provide supporters with exclusive extras and cool bonus perks.  

Barrowmaze II is the second part of a two-part exploration-style megadungeon for Labyrinth Lord and other classic fantasy role-playing games. BMII is a continuation of the initial "dungeon sprawl" concept presented in Barrowmaze I (BMI) and is intended for mid-and-high level characters.

BMI was a self-funded project published in early February for introductory to mid-level play. You can find it at rpgnow.

Barrowmaze I and II combine into one large megadungeon. However, they can also be played independently and are self-contained. You can find links, updates, fan-creations, and freebies at the Barrowmaze website.

“I’m hard pressed to find any real faults with Barrowmaze. Nearly everything about the product is well done, from the layout to the artwork to the content and cartography. Indeed, Barrowmaze is nearly a textbook example of how to make a compelling, well-presented dungeon module.” Grognardia

“I had never heard the acronym OSR stand for “Oh S!@t! Run!” before reading Barrowmaze, but it certainly fits.” Tenkar's Tavern

“Barrowmaze is the dungeon I wish I had written, and I can’t offer any higher praise than that.” Tales From the Flaming Faggot

“The author has used some interesting techniques to reinforce the theme of plundering long sealed tombs. There are frequent calls for excavation, or smashing through bricked up walls, to reach the hidden room beyond; much of the treasure is interred in burial catacombs (niches) carved into the walls, which require careful searching. Time is always a factor.” Dreams in the Lich House

Despite the success of Barrowmaze I it was a self-funded project with limited resources. There were things I wanted to add to the dungeon - including maps (print and digital) and additional art - but couldn't given the budget. Your support in this campaign will help me to address both issues and make Barrowmaze II bigger and better.

In terms of the dungeon itself, BMII includes the following new sections:

The Secret Shrine of Set: This section details the Necromancers of Set, a powerful faction in Barrowmaze. They continue their exploration of the dungeon in the hope of claiming the Tablet of Chaos as their own.

The Forbidden Crypts: A collapsed burial mound has given entry to a new power group that has aligned with the Acolytes of Orcus.

The Temple of Orcus: Militant, well-armed, and devoted - each of these describes the Acolytes of Orcus. They recently added some muscle to their ranks and hope to destroy the Necromancers and their "false" god Set. They must obtain the Tablet or face the wrath of The-One-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.

The Vault of the Unholy Relic: The followers of Nergal entombed the Tablet of Chaos deep in Barrowmaze - in a set of crypts covered in traps, illusions, and death. Nergal's most powerful followers remain to guard the relic, including the reclusive Keeper of the Tablet.

The Lair of Ossithrax Pejorative: Long after the flight of Nergal's followers from Barrowmaze, but centuries before the arrival of tomb-robbers intent on plundering the tombs for gold, an ancient black dragon lived and died on his hoard beneath a great burial mound he carved out as his lair. This great evil has heard the call of the Tablet of Chaos...

In addition to these dark and fascinating areas to explore, Barrowmaze II is loaded with new, interesting treasure types, traps, and monsters.

Art that celebrates classic fantasy gaming and dungeon-exploration is very important to me, and is central to the Barrowmaze project.

For Barrowmaze II artist Stefan Poag returns as does the talented Zhu Bajie. The wonderful Trevor Hammond illustrates a number of the undead for BMII. Trevor's style is so dark, macabre, and strange that it just would not be Barrowmaze without him.

In addition, several new artists are contributing illustrations including Scott LeMien, Alexander Cook, Stephan Thompson, and Cory Hamel. Cory, a reader of my blog Discourse and Dragons, commented on one of my posts and since that time we have been working together on BMII. He is Canadian, insanely talented, and a big TSR geek like me - all good.

Also, Cory will draw the digital map for BMII from my notes in both classic blue and black and white.

Alongside a bunch of new full and half page illustrations, I'm thrilled to report that every entry in the monster section will have a corresponding illustration - and I mean all of them. It will be a sight to behold.

WAIT! There's more!

I was always very interested in having one of the ex-TSR artists I grew up with contribute to BMI, but as I mentioned funding did not allow it. Undeterred, I recently contacted ex-TSR artist Jim Holloway to see if he would be interested in contributing to Barrowmaze II. Jim worked on First and Second Edition, as well as both Dungeon and Dragon magazines, and illustrated one of my favorite classic modules of all-time - B4 The Lost City, by Tom Moldvay. Much to my surprise, he was very keen and interested in the project. We worked out the details and I am thrilled to announce that Jim has signed-on to contribute several illustrations for Barrowmaze II - including a colour cover illustration. Woot!

I will start posting some of Jim's illustrations as soon as they are available.

Although you saw it at the top of the page, I would like to take a moment to talk about Stefan Poag's painting. This was a lot of fun to do and highlights the terrible Ossithrax Pejorative!

We started with the characters from the cover of Barrowmaze I. We decided that several were eaten by ravenous monsters. With the exception of the magic-user, we pulled the other characters from the interior art of BMI. It includes my personal Poag favorite - a paladin from the Holy Order of the Field Goal. He also gets channel 6 with that snappy headgear.

The second illustration depicts the tragic-character Dhekeon - the Skeleton Warrior. He plays an important role in the dungeon (I'll say no more) and is illustrated by Cory Hamel.

Estimated Delivery Date: October 2012.

All Supporters: Everyone who supports the campaign will be listed in an appendix at their level of support.

Devil Horns: You will have my thanks for helping out. All support, regardless of the level, is greatly appreciated.

Ravenous Dead: At this level you will receive the bookmarked PDF of Barrowmaze II

Son of Gaxx: At this level you will receive the bookmarked PDF and hardcover of Barrowmaze II. This includes shipping to your location in Canada, the United States, or the United Kingdom.

Crypt Knight: At this level you will receive the bookmarked PDF and numbered hardcover of Barrowmaze II. You will also receive a printed poster map (17x21) and the digital maps (classic blue and black and white). This includes shipping to your location in Canada, the United States, or the United Kingdom. EDIT (April 26): In addition, all those who contribute at the level of Crypt Knight or higher will automatically receive the custom Barrowmaze Dice!

*Numbered hardcovers will include a certificate that indicates the publication number of your book (__ of __) in the first print run. Numbered hardcovers will only be available to those who participate in the Indiegogo campaign (at this level or higher).

*The printed poster map, crafted by artist Cory Hamel, will be approximately 17x21 and printed in classic blue only. The map will be neatly folded and placed inside your hardcover for shipping to your location. Print maps will only be available to those who participate in the Indiegogo campaign (at this level or higher).

*The digital map will be handy for those of you who want to use your tablets or laptops at the table. You receive the digitial map in both 1) classic blue and 2) black and white.

*Barrowmaze Custom Dice (see Updates for more information)

Barrow Wight: At this level you will receive the bookmarked PDF and numbered hardcover of Barrowmaze II. You will also receive a printed poster map (17x21) and the digital maps (classic blue and black and white). Your hardcopy will be signed and inscribed by the author. This includes shipping to your location in Canada, the United States, or the United Kingdom.

*If your book is signed/inscribed, I will sign, date, and provide an inscription, dedication, or epigraph (or epitaph!). If you have something specific you would like written on the inside, or intend it as a gift, just let me know.

The Barrowmazening: This Perk includes everything at the Barrow Wight level plus a hardcopy of Barrowmaze I signed and inscribed by the author.

Keeper of the Tablet: At this level you will receive the bookmarked PDF and two numbered hardcovers of Barrowmaze II (EDIT: or a copy of Barrowmaze I and II). You will also receive a printed poster map (17x21) and the digital maps (classic blue and black and white). Your hardcopies will be signed and inscribed by the author. This includes shipping to your location in Canada, the United States, or the United Kingdom.

*In addition, and in the spirit of old school lethality, I will place the name (or remains) of one of your favorite deceased PCs in Barrowmaze II. A number of Barrowmaze game reports are available online. I've linked to many of these at the Barrowmaze website and Discourse and Dragons. If you already had a character meet their fate in Barrowmaze I (or elsewhere), and want their name placed in a crypt or their bones reanimated for BMII, be sure to select The Keeper of the Tablet perk. I'll work with you to create something cool that reflects your former PC's untimely demise. If you would prefer to have an anagram of your name, that would fine too. 

Ossithrax Pejorative: At this level you will receive the bookmarked PDF and two numbered hardcovers of Barrowmaze II (EDIT: or a copy of Barrowmaze I and II). You will also receive a printed poster map (17x21) and the digital maps (classic blue and black and white). Your hardcopies will be signed and inscribed by the author. This includes shipping to your location in Canada, the United States, or the United Kingdom.

*If you want to take part in the creative process, and have an interesting monster idea, select Ossithrax Pejoritive. I'll work with you to include the new monster in Barrowmaze II. You can choose the artist of your preference (Stefan Poag, Zhu Bajie, Trevor Hammond, or Cory Hamel) to illustrate your custom creature.

He-Who-Shall-Not-Be-Named: At this level you will receive two bookmarked PDFs and two numbered hardcovers of Barrowmaze II (EDIT: or a copy of Barrowmaze I and II). You wil also receive two printed poster maps (17x21) and two copies of the digital maps (classic blue and black and white) your hardcopies will be signed and inscribed by the author. This includes shipping to your location in Canada, the United States or the United Kingdom and five sets of the custom dice.

*In addition, I will work with you on the following projects:

1) to insert the name of one of your deceased PCs (or an anagram of your name) into BMII. 

2) to create a monster employing an artist of your choice (Poag, Hamel, Hammond, or Zhu).

3) to create a full page B/W illustration employing an artist of your choice (Poag, Hamel, Hammond, or Zhu)

I have a Bonus Perk currently on double-secret probation. I will reveal the perk if we reach the first goal of $4,000.

If we pass the $7,000 mark all those who pledged at the level of Crypt Knight or higher will receive a Tomb of Horrors-style printed illustration-booklet depicting special keyed dungeon rooms.

If we pass the $10,000 mark all those who pledged at the level of Crypt Knight or higher will receive a map-as-art print illustrated by Cory Hamel.  This map will be done from the perspective of the dungeon-explorers and will make a great wall-print. These maps will only be available to those who participate in the Indiegogo campaign at the stated level or higher. EDIT -- extended to 12k to accomodate Barrowmaze I illustration booklet.

Additional Perks are ready in the event we exceed these goals.

If you are located outside the above three countries please get in touch and I will do my best to find a shipping rate that works for you. Please keep in mind that postal rates are higher in Canada than the US.

Greg Gillespie has been playing role-playing games since the early 1980s. I am a university professor and PhD graduate from The University of Western Ontario in the fields of cultural history and cultural studies. I recently supervised a Master of Arts student who examined aesthetics and the OSR, and in 2011 taught a course on the history and culture of role-playing games. I also maintain the OSR blog Discourse and Dragons and am co-creator of Meatshields! The Classic Fantasy Hireling and Henchman Generator. I live in the Niagara Region of Ontario, Canada with my wife, daughter, son, and our dog Max.

Thank you for taking the time to read this campaign. Those of you who purchased BMI know that it was a labour of love and can expect the same level of creativity in Barrowmaze II. If you have any questions be sure to leave a comment or get in touch. Please be sure to spread the word via your social networking outlets - blogs, forums, facebook, twitter, etc. The grapevine is the best way to spread the word to the OSR community.

Thank you, Greg \m/

story:
I just want more games because my parents won't buy me destiny on the ps4, my intentional goal is $70 but the money goal won't go any lower than $500.

If you donate or not you can watch me play ps4 games ( maybe you'll like it or you won't either way try it)at http://www.twitch.tv/blaxeking to know when I'll be doing gameplays follow me at twitter: https://twitter.com/Bladekil1 

Also some of you might be thinking what does this campaign have to do anything with the penguin pictures? Well I love penguins.
