Oceanside Community Service, Inc. (OCS) is an all volunteer registered non-profit established in 1949 to aid those in need within the Community of Oceanside, Long Island and assisting surrounding communities.
Oceanside, Long Island and it's surrounding commmunities were ravaged by not only hurricane sandy but a nor'easter a week later as well.  Everything from homes to businesses to cars to schools were flooded, damaged and destroyed.
Hundreds of thousands lost power in the region and were without power, heat, hot water or garbage pickup.  The damage will in the millions.  See the video above that shows some of the terrible damage to this community.
OCS has already been providing these couragoeus services in the wake of this disaster:

Salvaged and transferred 600 cases of sub-zero frozen food from Oceanside High School and transferred to “The INN” (the Interfaith Food Network) which operates 17 soup kitchens and housing for the homeless and battered women and children on Long Island. Oceanside High School lost power for 5+ days and therefore the food would have had to be thrown out. Quick thinking by the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools allowed the food to be donated.
Coordinated with High School staff and cooked, packed planned delivery routes, got volunteers to knock on doors as well as get drivers to use precious gas to deliver over 7,000 hot Meals to those who had been subsisting on cold food, no heat, no electricity and storm damaged homes whose damages are indescribable – you have to see the pictures to believe it.
Set up warming station locally outside of FEMA and Governmental control. FEMA and OEM (Nassau County Emergency Management) facilities were not located where those affected could get to once everyone lost their cars and long gas lines kicked in. We recognized this early on and adjusted to circumstances and were able deliver hot food as noted above.
Set up a shopping pantry for residents to come and take  non-perishable food – not MRE”s to sustain families during this crisis.
Set up a clothing boutique for those in need of clothes as well as provided cleaning supplies to help in the cleans up.
Delivered food by bicycle when the gas lines were long and people out of Town needed food to tide them over.

These volunteers have been phenomenal and need our support.
The Community FoodBank of New Jersey (www.cfbnj.org/sandy )
Today, the FoodBank distributes 39 million pounds of food and groceries a year, ultimately serving 1,500 non-profit programs including 436 programs served by its Partner Distribution Organizations (PDOs). Through their combined efforts, they help to feed 900,000 low-income people in 18 of New Jersey’s 21 counties.
CFBNJ has been distributing over 100,000 lbs of food daily to families displaced by Hurricane Sandy.
The Community FoodBank of New Jersey has been working closely with New Jersey Voluntary Organization Active in Disaster (VOAD), the Red Cross, and the Salvation Army to respond to the needs of the many New Jersey Residents who have been affected by the devastation.
A designated 501(c)(3) charitable organization, the Community Foodbank of New Jersey is a member of Feeding America, the nation’s largest network of food banks, as well as a member of the New Jersey Federation of food banks which includes ourSouthern Branch, the Food Bank of South Jersey, and our three Partner Distribution Organizations (PDOs): FoodBank of Monmouth & Ocean Counties, Mercer Street Friends Food Bank and NORWESCAP Food Bank.
Our Mission
Our mission is to fight hunger and poverty in New Jersey by assisting those in need and seeking long term solutions.  We will engage, educate, and empower all sectors of society in the battle.

What We Need & What You Get
We are hoping to raise $35,000 for amazing causes. Please read out perks to the right!  We'll do whatever we can to help you donate!
What will your money do?  Great question! K.I.D.S. needs our help to get neccessities for those hurricane victimes including clothes, books, shoes, undergarments, juvenile products, home goods and homecare products. With the holidays approaching OCS is needs to continue their great work to aid the families of Oceanside and surrounding burroughs with non-perishable food for at least 2 weeks. CFBNJ has been distributing over 100,000 lbs of food daily to families displaced by Hurricane Sandy.
Here are some numbers that show the impact your donations can make!


 $20 will provide underwear, socks, a shirt, pants and shoes for four children
 $50 can help us provide $500 worth of hygiene products
 $110 will help K.I.D.S. distribute 1,000 blankets to victims of Hurricane Sandy
 $250 will provide $2,500 worth of winter shoes and bo $500 will provide 2,000 diapers for a shelter serving victims of Hurricane Sandy

 $1,000 can help us provide $10,000 worth of warm winter clothing and coats


We can make a big impact and we are hoping we can get your help.


*If you need to make a donation tax deductible, please contact us directly to make your donation at arcade@stiksgaming.com with a phone number we can reach you at.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please share our efforts with your friends and use indiegogo's share tools to get the word out.
If you do a help us out we might finally admit YOU won that game of Pac-Man we played in '86.

story:
What Is This Game, Why I Started Making It & What Makes It Special

Legends of the Seas is an unique free-to-play multiplayer strategy game that has you up against a friend or a random opponent in a tactical battle of the wits.

My inspiration for this game came from just sitting one day and pondering over the similarities and differences between board- and video games. I have always been a fan of board games that don't have any element of luck attached to them, no dice rolling, no card drawing and no spinning of wheels or anything similar. I mean games like Chess, Checkers, Go and Stratego, games that put you 100% in control of your fate. I came to sad realization that there aren't many video games like that, if any.

So I set out to create a spiritual successor to these games. A game that makes use of the advantages that video games present, while keeping true to the main key elements that made these games so great. The key elements for me are the absence of luck and the near infinite possibilities and strategies.

Here are some main features and goals of this game that I try to focus on:

  • Equal and fair playing field and game mechanics that minimize the element of luck and make this a truly competitive game.
  • Intuitive simultaneous turn-based gameplay with an awesome planning- and simulation phase.
  • Cross-platform playability. This game is going to be available on PCs, Mac's, iOS and Android devices so you could for example start a game on your Mac against a player on Android and finish it on your iOS device while he finishes it on his PC.
  • Easy to learn, difficult to master. It is a game that has a simple core concept but the strategies are nearly infinite.
  • Can be played in a way that suits the player most. Players who want to take their time strategizing can play a slower game where 1 turn can take up to a full day to complete and players who want quick action can choose a game mode where turns can take no longer than a minute or two.


What We Need & What You Get

However, to make this a good and successful game I will need your help:

  • Your funding helps me put my full focus on this project and keep the multiplayer servers live and depending on the amount of support I will be able to get premium resources(these include but are not limited to software licenses, sound effects, 3D models, textures, UI graphics and music) to make it a truly good looking, high quality game .
  • The more you contribute, the better I can make the game and the sooner it will be finished. By the game being better I have in mind creating more stages to play on, a larger variety of different ships, improve the graphics of the game, make the UI very neat and easily usable and have a lot of different game-modes.
  • For an Indie Developer with very little media reach the first players, supporters  and fans are extremely valuable and I want the supporters to realize that. That is why a lot of the perks have rewards that are exclusive to IndieGoGo supporters that no amount of money can buy after the campaign is over. Also, all of the perks have included with them an amount of in-game currency greater in value than the cost of the perk.
  • I am going to finish this game even if I do not reach my set goal, but the development will take longer and the final product will not reach its potential.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk for this project is not building up a large enough user-base which is essential for a multiplayer game to function. Also finding a way to keep this a free-to-play game and still be profitable while not making this a pay-to-win game.

To make this game playable even when there aren't a lot of active players I have planned to make the game playable over longer periods of time, where you will be notified when a match is found for you and when the opponent has made his move. That way you can close the app and return to it whenever you find suitable without having to wait for another active player. I will still need to work on making a good match making system, because in a game like this a suitable opponent is what makes the game really enjoyable.

And I have already figured out a great system to make the in-game currency relevant without making it a pay-to-win game. You don't have to worry about that as I don't want this to be a pay-to-win game no more than you do, as that would be going against everything that I created this game for.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, then there is still a couple of ways you can help:

  • Create an account on LotS website to show that you are interested in the game and you will receive a special early bird reward for having faith in the project once the game is launched.
  • Share this project with your friends! After you create an account on our website you will receive a personal referral link. Get your friends to join using this link for additional bonuses in the game when it launches. Special, extra valuable bonuses for people with most referrals.

Meet you soon in a battle, in the Legends of the Seas!

story:
About this project 


Volcano Birds is a free mobile touchscreen game. It is 1-player based, addicting, challenging and fun game. In the birdies’ happy world, the Volcano erupts and all birds are caught by the flames of the lava. The only one who can save them is you – our main hero, armed with a fire extinguisher and courage. You can help the birdies fly again.

Volcano Birds will be survival mode only. Your main goal will be to survive as long as you can and save as many birds as you can. The more birds you save the higher score you get.


Why INDIEGOGO? 

Our team consists of two people –my friend Maya – the visionary developer and myself, the game developer. We’ve already poured a lot of resources into this game for art & design, 2D objects, audio and other expenses. Indiegogo will allow us to go bigger and better than we could by going straight to retail. By using crowdfunding, we’ll cover manufacturing costs and print for outfits, boost our art budget, bring stretch goals to light, design better and funnier birds, marketing and advertising expenses, and more. 

The unique thing using Indiegogo is that only people who contribute to our project by this crowdfunding site will get our fun and cool outfits and even more, some of you will get the chance to name our main hero and some of the birds!

We hope to finish this project by mid-September this year and publish Volcano Birds by the end of September.

What’s the game inside

Here, we present some screenshots of the game still under development:


Even if you are not able to contribute to our project do not worry! Just be our friend, like our idea and spread the word! Do not forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you all for your time!

Have fun!

All the best!

Maya

Vehbi

story:
My name is Alex Wice, and I want to reward deserving players by continuing the Prismata Cup: the strongest field Hearthstone tournament ever.  

Until now, Hearthstone tournaments have been mostly invitationals with poor mobility for strong ladder and tournament players. I'm looking to change that.

 

The first Prismata Cup was already a resounding success and, at the time, the strongest field Hearthstone tournament to take place.  


With your support, we can build on that success.


This campaign is important to me because I care about Hearthstone and E-sports.  Prismata [the game] sponsors this cup, but the tournament can't survive forever under this umbrella. Soon it won't be worth it, and the Prismata Cup will be shut down.  

If you want a monthly major tournament with all the best Hearthstone players, and with open standards for who should qualify, you should support this event.

Your contribution goes 100% to the prizepool for the players, the casters, and the production.  I don't take a penny.

How is my money used?

For this tournament, we went with the bare minimum:

  • $2000 prizepool - just enough to attract almost all the best players

  • More than $1000 on casters and production.

The bare minimum budget that we need to stay afloat is $3000.  An artist friend and I both work for free on producing overlays and directing the tournament, respectively.


To make this tournament monthly (or bi-monthly), we'll need a steady stream of money from somewhere.  If we raise more money than that, then we’ll make the tournament even more awesome.

Why make Prismata Cup a regular tournament?

I believe Hearthstone sorely needs a regular tournament akin to Magic the Gathering's "Pro Tour" that celebrates the best players in the game (both familiar and unfamiliar) and give them exposure.

The Prismata Cup showcases the best Hearthstone play, which is exciting for viewers. It is also the tournament with the most open standards, with more than 90% of the players chosen from open standards published a month before the tournament.  We are looking to solidify these standards so that the tournament can be seen as the most legitimate, instead of just having the most popular players.

Are you capable of organizing such a tournament?

I've already delivered on Prismata Cup 1, and Prismata Cup 2 is well on its way.  Your donation will be used only to pay for future Prismata Cups, and I'm committed to regularly producing the best Hearthstone tournament ever.  

I promise that 100% of the money will be used for producing the best content possible, no matter what. Thank you for your support and donation.

Feel free to contact me directly with questions or any feedback (/u/awice on reddit.)

story:
"A pact was made among SKULLs, players from all the tribes of the Great North together  against everyone. If the Chaos Gods want them to play fantasy football, they will answer with blood of their enemies. A Minotaur, an Ogre, a Troll will be their Line; Chaotic Barbarians will follow causing Mayhem; a ratkin, a goblin and even an elf...they will play as DEVILS."

The SKULL DEVILS team can be played as Chaos Pact in our favorite Fantasy Football or as a Warband in skirmish games.

SKULL DEVILS, Concept & Models

BigGuys (Casted on Resin)





Chaotic Barbarians (Casted on white metal)

b1 b2 b3 (Concept) Claw, barbarian lineman, two head (pending)

b4 b5 (Concept) extra arm, claw

b6 Big Hand Big Hand/mighty blow b7 Horns (pending)

b8 Tentacle

The Other races (Casted on white metal)




Chaotic Ratskin (with extra head and extra hand)


Barbarian Goblin







 










10k Goal (Accessories) and 14k (Coach) have been switched as well as 12k (Accesories) and 17k (Apothecary)

ADD-ONS




Who are we?

We are the Goblinguild, a miniature club. We are making miniatures for more than two years by now. You can check our works in our Facebook page. We are miniature fans who want to make the miniatures that we want to play with.
After our first campaign of the Green Ratz (mutated goblins and skinrats miniatures for Underworld teams) was a success, we want to continue with the Skull Devils, a Chaos Pact team. We still need you to speed up the release through crowdfunding. So we bring you our concepts with some of the miniatures already sculpted and if you help to fund it, we will cast them for you. We count with Pedro Ramos to sculpt this team because he is the best sculptor in Fantasy Football scene.

Risk and challenges. 

We have learned from our first campaign. We know what was more difficult for us and we have taken meassures to better our mistakes, mostly in having delays to ship perks.  We have almost half of the team already sculpted, so we will need less time to complete the team. But our quality standards will mantain, the best takes time. WE WONT RUSH PEDRO. We want the best miniatures possible so he will take as long as he needs. He is a professional sculptor and can work with other projects meanwhile. Take in mind delaying is a possibility but you will have a great team.     

If You like our Idea, please Share with your friends.
If you dont like anything about campaign, comment.

 

Estimate Shipping Date June 2017

Shipping is not included

 

Frequent Questions

Why is estimate shipping date is so long if FF companies ship faster?
This project isn't a preorder. We have to make all production process after campaign funds. We estimate that we will need that time to be sure we can make a quality team. We will try to shorten this time without dismishing the Team  quality. In our first campaign, some of the perks were shipped one month before the shipping date and some were shipped one month after.
Can I purchase a single model?
Not during the campaign, After we sent all pledges we will have them available. No, not even big guys.
How do the team will be cast?
Regular players will be cast on white metal and BigGuys will be casted on resin. from previous campaign we have learned this formula has the best results. By now, they wont be in other materials.

And that's all, Folks.

story:
TICKETS NOW AVAILABLE ON EVENTBRITE

If you missed your chance for early bird tickets, don't worry! You can now head to Eventbrite  for your tickets!

http://gdx2016.eventbrite.ca


WHEN

Date: May 7th and May 8th

Time: 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM on both days

There is a dev-only networking mixer on Friday, May 6th, 2016 - presenters get free tickets. (There’s a perk for attendees to go below!)

WHERE

The location of GDX 2016 is at The Heart (9-100) in MacEwan University, on the corner of 109 St and 104 Ave. Parking is available on location.

The dev-only networking event will be on the second floor of The Heart at MacEwan University.

WHAT
The Game Plan: Our Program

GDX is a celebration of games and game development in Alberta. We bring the community together - game developers can network with industry professionals and showcase their work to the public; players can play new video games and board games, try out new hardware in the developer fair, compete in tournaments, and enjoy a program of panels and speakers.

Our first event was a rousing success. GDX 2015 had:

  • Over 650 attendees, from “AAA” game creators, to indie devs, to game players;

  • over 40 teams of presenters in our developer fair;

  • 4 professional development panels (computing science, interdisciplinary game development, indie game development in Edmonton, and serious games);

  • 2 seasoned game developer speakers (Trent Oster of Beamdog, and Mickey MacDonald of Microsoft);

  • the UAlberta CMPUT 250 Awards Ceremony; and

  • various game tournaments!

We are bringing back all of this content and more for GDX 2016. We’re looking to host more presenters, more content, all in a bigger venue!


Have a look at what our perk tiers look like! We’re using Indiegogo as a platform for ticket pre-sales, fundraising, and distributing a GDX 2016 Game Bundle. 

The game bundle is for DAWT, RunGunJumpGun, and AsterVoid 2000, which will support EgoAnt Productions, 33 Games, and Mad Capacity. We have been following the development of these games closely, and we know you will love them! You will be sent steam keys when the games come out!



$12 000 - Funding Goal Reached!
We’ve hit our goal and GDX 2016 will be just as good (if not better) than last year’s event.

$14 000 - Professional Videography for Panels

Didn’t get a chance to see our panels? No worries, we’ll get a professional videographer to film our most popular panels!

$16 000 - Tourney Awards, Prizes & Trophies

The pot will be sweetened for select tournaments throughout the weekend.

$20 000 - Upgraded Venue

If we’ve hit this mark, it means that GDX 2016 is popular enough to warrant a bigger venue! More space, more booths, and more fun!

$25 000 - Long-Term Sustainability

If we reach $25K, GDX 2017 will for sure be happening! Any additional money that we make will be used to make GDX 2017 a better event.

$1.00 M - We Invite Hideo Kojima
By popular demand, we’ll invite Mr. Hideo Kojima himself to GDX 2016. (No promises that he’ll actually attend!)


Here is a preview of the games that come in the GDX 2016 Game Bundle!




Here is a breakdown of our spending. All of the money we bring in goes towards supporting the game development community through GDX - the funds are going to our high cost items: venue costs, utilities (mainly power), lanyards for attendees, and volunteer appreciation items. 

Our goal is to continue raising the profile of hardworking game developers and the game development industry, and to connect you with the games of some incredible local developers.  If our event aids in the creation of sustainable, full-fledged studios opening in Alberta, we would consider our efforts a resounding success!

While GDX 2016 can run on less than $12 000, we want to make the event special. The $12 000 goal will help make GDX 2016 the best event it can be. That $12,000 includes our many sponsors, which will be included in the campaign total. If the campaign fails to reach its goal, the members planning GDX 2016 are dedicated to covering the costs themselves. Any funds raised above and beyond of our goal will be used to ensure that GDX is an annual event that gamers and game developers can look forward to for years to come. 



FOR PRESENTERS

If you’re a game creator and you want to showcase your work at GDX 2016, you can find our presenter application here.

We want game creators from all walks of life and you don’t need a demo to present. If you have a portfolio of art, music, writing, voice work, or any sort of games-related content, you should sign up! Both projects (game demos) and portfolios (samples of work) are highly desirable. Space is limited so sign  up now!

Please note that presenting at GDX 2016 means you are automatically invited to our networking event on Friday, May 6, 2016.


FOR VOLUNTEERS

We are always in need of volunteers! Whether it’s day-of helpers helping put on GDX 2016, or committed enthusiasts who want to help grow game development in Alberta, we welcome everyone to come and join in! You can find our volunteer application here.


FOR EVERYONE!

Help spread the word! We hope people will see our ads shortly, but positive word of mouth and social media is always appreciated.
story_txt:
TICKETS NOW AVAILABLE ON EVENTBRITEIf you missed your chance for early bird tickets, don't worry! You can now head to Eventbrite  for your tickets!http://gdx2016.eventbrite.caWHEN
Date: May 7th and May 8thTime: 9:00 AM to 4:00 PM on both daysThere is a dev-only networking mixer on Friday, May 6th, 2016 - presenters get free tickets. (There’s a perk for attendees to go below!)WHEREThe location of GDX 2016 is at The Heart (9-100) in MacEwan University, on the corner of 109 St and 104 Ave. Parking is available on location.The dev-only networking event will be on the second floor of The Heart at MacEwan University.WHATThe Game Plan: Our ProgramGDX is a celebration of games and game development in Alberta. We bring the community together - game developers can network with industry professionals and showcase their work to the public; players can play new video games and board games, try out new hardware in the developer fair, compete in tournaments, and enjoy a program of panels and speakers.Our first event was a rousing success. GDX 2015 had:
Over 650 attendees, from “AAA” game creators, to indie devs, to game players;
over 40 teams of presenters in our developer fair;
4 professional development panels (computing science, interdisciplinary game development, indie game development in Edmonton, and serious games); 
2 seasoned game developer speakers (Trent Oster of Beamdog, and Mickey MacDonald of Microsoft);
the UAlberta CMPUT 250 Awards Ceremony; and
various game tournaments!
We are bringing back all of this content and more for GDX 2016. We’re looking to host more presenters, more content, all in a bigger venue!

Have a look at what our perk tiers look like! We’re using Indiegogo as a platform for ticket pre-sales, fundraising, and distributing a GDX 2016 Game Bundle. 
The game bundle is for DAWT, RunGunJumpGun, and AsterVoid 2000, which will support EgoAnt Productions, 33 Games, and Mad Capacity. We have been following the development of these games closely, and we know you will love them! You will be sent steam keys when the games come out!



$12 000 - Funding Goal Reached!We’ve hit our goal and GDX 2016 will be just as good (if not better) than last year’s event.$14 000 - Professional Videography for PanelsDidn’t get a chance to see our panels? Any funds raised above and beyond of our goal will be used to ensure that GDX is an annual event that gamers and game developers can look forward to for years to come.

If you’re a game creator and you want to showcase your work at GDX 2016, you can find our presenter application here.

story:
Mighty Forests of Kalnik is a sandbox survival castle building RTS, placed in an open world, during the trying medieval times. It follows the new standards set by games such as “Rimworld”, “Kenshi”, “Timber and Stone”, “7 Days to Die” and “Factorio” (even though some are played quite differently), ideas and features which show the respect for players’ intelligence. The Mighty Forests story takes place in the deep Kalnik forests. Unexpected events brought your group of 5 people there, and the best course of action for you is to build yourself a sturdy place to live and survive the unexplored wilderness.

 

Story

Once upon a time, a long time ago, there was a large and strong kingdom and its two major towns. Or, were those actually two separate kingdoms? I can’t really remember, the records dating back to that age are neither frequent nor very legible. Anyway, between those two towns there are forests of Kalnik, a vast stretch of woods and clearings, hills and plains. No matter how idyllic it may sound, the forest actually conceals a plethora of wonders and dangers, the nature of which is unknown to any civilized soul.

Then, as it usually occurs, the people living in the first town had a wish to connect to the other town by a new direct road, and not just by the old and winding one, going for miles and miles all the way around the forests of Kalnik. There had been some minor earlier attempts to build a road, yet they all had failed. However, one day, the King ordered a thousand swordsmen and a thousand archers from each town to protect the road builders.

The work lasted for a very long time, and a number of victims were reported on all sides. Nevertheless, the road was eventually completed.

As it turned out, travelling through the forests of Kalnik involved many a risk. Some people used to rely on their ability to break into a run in case of necessity, others trusted reliable guards... The only thing that was certain was, that anyone you ran into in the forests of Kalnik did not happen to be there because of their own goodwill, but rather due to a great misfortune and dire necessity. Or greed.

 

Many years later, the road was still a bit grassy and in disrepair, yet by no means impassable. There had been no major incident reported in the forests of Kalnik for a while, so the King plucked up courage and decided to send a hundred soldiers to venture way deeper into the forest.

That very evening, the soldiers returned. They reported to have heard some eerie sounds and noticed some uncanny commotion, but nothing more blatant than that.

The following day, the King dispatched the hundred-strong patrol again. Like on the previous day, they all returned, but this time they did not appear to be so terrified.

 

On the third day, they went on patrol, marching steadily. They were never seen again. This is where my story begins.

 

Three scenarios

The King’s unsuccessful venture into the Kalnik Forests was followed by an unexpected series of events which changed lives of three groups of people dramatically, and forced them to start anew in the middle of the forest.

Gita and the Jesters: agile skillful people accompanied by a girl named Gita

Noble Oto: a nobleman with a firm plan and an attitude

Shtef and the lost soldiers: highly trained in military skills, but lost otherwise

I won’t tell you their full stories just yet (even though the last one is pretty obvious). I want you to read them as you start the game the first time, so they can set the right mood at the right moment.

 

Creatures

Settlers

You start with 5 + 1 settlers. Your settlers have skills and knowledge how to build, mine, farm, hunt, fight. Their work is assigned via our Tasks engine. You create tasks (dig a hole here, farm there, craft hammers), define which storage to use, choose which settlers are best suited for the task and assign them. The settlers need to eat and sleep. They can die, and ( for the time being ) they cannot get sick. Every now and then, you'll encounter other humans which might be willing to join you. And your clan, if treated right, will grow their numbers up to a few hundred souls.

 

+ 1 settler

Depending on which of the 3 game scenarios you choose, you'll get one "different" settler. Some might say those settlers has some special abilities, I would say that they just have a special kind of view on the Life, the Universe and Everything. But more about that later.

 

Animals

Animals are using the same task engine as Settlers do. Why? First, it was smarter to code it that way. Second, it allows animals to do things, not just stand around and attack/flee on sight. For instance, Mighty Forests deer can and will sneak in on your fields and eat your crops. There are wolves, bears, deer, rabbits and we plan to add a dozen more.

 

Other "civilized" creatures

You are not the only "civilized" creature in the Forest. There are others, and they have their own places to live, they run their own tasks (assigned to them by Clan AI), the same way as your settlers run theirs. They will chop wood, work on farms, mine and build, craft. And maybe they'll be nice to you. Most of the creatures in Kalnik Forests are from Slavic mythology. Some will build their own towns, some will try to steal from you and bring loot to their lair. Some will roam free and react on encountering you, maybe attack on sight, or ask for help.

There are giants in Forests. And you will be able to build siege engines. A castle- building game without giants and siege engines is not a good castle-building game.

 

Clans

Your settlers belong to one clan. Every herd of deer or wolves belongs to different clans. The clans have relationship status towards one another, depending on the creature type and past events. So the deer will avoid your settlers and wolves, the wolves will hunt deer, lone settlers and even steal your food in wintertime, or fight another wolves’ clan for game.

 

Nights

On some peaceful nights your settlers will fall into deep sleep in which they'll suddenly take control over an existing nearby clan (herd of animals, or any other clan). They'll be able to do tasks which those creatures can do. And you can use this new transformation to enjoy the night out, or to help your settlers in some way. You could use one clan of wolves against another, or to scare and drive deer into your bows range. Or use moles to find an iron vein quickly. It's a new feature in RTS gaming (AFAIK), sounds great and should fit into early game boring nights really well. Why look at your settlers sleep, when you can run through the hills as a wolf?

 

World

The map is endless. In all directions. You can mine and mine and you'll never reach the bottom. You can finally build the tallest tower in the world. Or walls which would shame the Great Wall to tears.

Kalnik is a mountain in Europe, covered in mighty forests, full of inspiring nature and history.

 

Road

A road runs through the whole map, generates tunnels if mountains are too high, creates bridges if it runs over a lake. When you connect your settlement to the road, and put out the sign, road venturers might visit your settlement if they find you relevant to their needs and plans. For example, you'll be relevant to passing traders if you do a lot of trading. People in need will more often knock on your doo... hmm.. castle gate if you are famous for helping others.

Not building a connection to the road won't spare you occasional visits by friendly bandits who just want your metal, or a trader running from the wolves. It'll just greatly reduce venturers coming from the road, and not all of the Kalnik creatures use roads to travel.

 

Structural integrity (or gravity)

To make building castles, villages and even landscapes even more satisfying, we have added gravity. Well, a kind of gravity, we call it a Structural integrity controller.

Most importantly, it takes care of those blocks hanging in the air, once it was mined under it or a catapult destroyed some blocks when the projectile hit the wall. Those blocks are going to properly drop to the ground as Newton predicted.

Don’t worry, your builders and miners know that and they’ll avoid such mistakes. And, if skilled enough, they will warn you about problems in building plans you are currently drawing.

But also it’ll “use the force of gravity” on your buildings if you don’t have enough supporting walls for that glorious ceiling, or if you planned to build the entire castle on one pillar. I know, it’s easier to defend that way, but really...

Every building material has a defined clinging force, so building your ceiling using only sand will just make your floors covered in sand and your (low skill) builders confused.

 

Blueprints

Did it ever happen to you that you finish a nice and advanced north city wall, and then you realize you have to do the same thing three more times? Or you keep looking at the beauty of that tower and wishing you can easily build the same one, rotated, in several more places? Well, worry no more, Mighty Forests has blueprints.

You can mark any 3D area and create blueprint of whatever blocks are built within. You can rotate the blueprint, mirror (left-right mirror, not upside-down so the roof goes down, but I'm willing to add that feature if you push me). You can share your blueprints between your games AND on the Forums via the in-game menu.

Be aware though, I'll look at the best published blueprints and I WILL steal the best designs and show them to the bad guys, and teach them how to build them quickly and use them on your map against you.

 

Tasks engine runs our world

Our Tasks engine is running the show in Mighty Forests. It took months to plan a good and easy-to-use concept, and then a few more to code this beauty. Once applied to a creature, it gives a total freedom in setting up settler jobs.

The idea behind the engine was simple, we wanted an engine which could do this: I want 3 of my settlers to work on these two farmlands (Task 1). Once there is no more work on those farmlands , 2 of them should work on third farmland (Task 2), and the one left should continue working on manufacturing planks (Task 3). Once the logs run out of the selected input storage, he will haul more logs from other storages using a cart to bring more per trip done (Task 4). And once everything is done, they should equip swords and start training on some dummies(Task 5).

 

And that we did. Each task can have input-specific input storage, output storage, workstation and workers. And each creature can have a sortable list of such tasks. And using a carefully planned UI, setting and reviewing tasks configuration is intuitive and fast.

Some tasks are really simple, like “You go here”, but some tasks can have more advanced setup, like “this settler should craft 3 best quality iron swords (since he’s my best smith), he should take iron ingots from the closest storage, work on this lvl 3 smithy and store swords in this armoury once they are done”

 

Skills and research

You learn and research by working

We want our armoursmiths to level up their armour-crafting skill while crafting armour. It's the way most of today’s games work. And that's great. But when it comes to research, even stone-age research, it's usually done by "scientists" standing in front of the table and discovering better ways to farm or better armour designs.

It wasn't like that back then. There were no "scientists" in those villages and castles. There were hard working people who had good ideas. Who were not just working, they were also learning and experimenting and researching while working. Who is in a better position to discover or reproduce some advanced armour design than the person who actually spends days producing armours?

 

In almost every task you can divide work-time between three areas: producing, learning and researching; with minimum of 5% in any area.

How does that work? Let’s say a passing trader ordered a big shipment of advanced shields. But, you don’t even know how to produce such an advanced shield. So you set the armoursmith to mainly do research while crafting shields by setting research timeshare to a maximum. Once the armoursmith managed to reach the desired advancement, you switch from mainly research to mainly production, thus speeding up production, to quickly fulfill the order.

 

Research tree

In order to keep it simple, we’ve organized all the research areas to have five levels, from primitive to the “most advanced technology in medieval ages”. Every tool, every armour and weapon can be crafted in five different quality variants, with the highest quality requiring additional gold and silver for crafting to make it truly legendary.

We have also included the research for workstations upgrades, so you can research and build bigger, better (and more beautiful) smithies. Or farms, each upgrade level for farming brings something new, not just an increase in yield.

Farms with an irrigation upgrade need to be weeded more often and they yield more, farms with a permaculture upgrade need less work and, as for some food cultures, they don’t require reseeding.

 

Fame

We are playing with the idea to add fame scores in the game, divided in few categories, like Innkeeping, Trading, Crafting, Military, Helpfulness.

Yes, that would mean that you'll be able to receive guests, feed them and rent rooms. And they will spread the word about your hospitality and hopefully pay you for the service received. Or become a famous smith and take pride in the best axes for miles around.

This won't be included in the first release, as we need to leave something for the future updates ;-).

I would prefer to have a ( virtually ) bug-free game ready for Alpha 1 release, rather than trying to cover all the ideas we have.

 

Game’s development stage

Codewise, the game is ready for the basic/advanced play. All of the main features are done and tested. You can Build, Mine, Farm, Craft, Chop wood, Gather, Fish, Hunt, Haul, Tailor, Eat, Sleep, Train, Guard, Patrol, Follow, Protect, Fight (ranged and melee), Import/export building blueprints... and it all works well.

What we lack is UI and models/animations. We have basic models with basic animations, most of which are attack animations. Right now we are using Attack slash animation for wood chopping, thrust animation for sawing and Dead animation for sleeping. That is why this is the area of the game that will get most attention during the next two months from our new 3D guy/girl (if the campaign succeeds), right after we finish implementing the UI. Ivan did a great job on UI framework, so it’s a piece of cake now to add buttons with all kinds of possibilities.

We have already finished the first 20% of the UI and the framework is doing great, all of the features planned to be in UI are prototyped and working.

 

Why crowdfunding?

This Campaign isn't here to determine if this game will get developed or not. It will.

I got a full written permission from my wife that I am allowed to develop this game full-time for another 6 months. Signed and verified by all the recognized authorities. And trust me (or ask Ivan), I can write loads of good code within that time period. And even some bad one too.

We’ve created this campaign to:

  • Get some funds to hire 3D animator now, rather than later
  • See public reaction to the game, story, gameplay and game features
  • Create an active player community

And to set proper goals for investing time into the visual parts of the game, since it costs a lot of time to do it really nicely. I don't need Mighty Forests of Kalnik to look perfect, but I know some of you do, and I have nothing against that.

What I want to accomplish with this game is to create an advanced intelligent game through smart and innovative features, which will really make you think and plan and adopt. Like Rimworld, or Factorio. Because that's the kind of game I want to play and develop.

 

And some of the features presented here are actually really good features, aren't they? So, this is the deal I'm offering:

- if Mighty Forests crowdfunding campaign fails, you'll get your money back, I'll invest 6 more months, full time, into the game, and start selling it soon through game site and probably Steam. That should be enough to convince my wife that I'm not completely crazy, I hope.

- if we do collect the specified amount right now, we’ll hire a 3D animator straight away, the game will get developed faster and into a more beautiful world to jump in.

- and if we collect 500,000, I'll found a proper primary school in my hometown, where my kids will learn how to think and not how to ... well, you know.

And I'll develop the game like crazy, of course.

 

Ivan and I each have 15+ years of development experience and have worked on number of large-scale applications. We cannot anticipate every problem that might arise, nobody can do that, but we know how to plan with future unknown problems in mind.

We have enough funding for at least 6 more months even if we don't get a dime, and in that time 2 senior developers can create a miracle, especially when motivated like we are.

So, as long as no huge fast-moving space rock hits our planet, we'll be good and Mighty Forests of Kalnik will become a full-release game.

 

The Team

Core team:

Karlo - That’s me. I started pondering on this idea for a game a few years ago. It took me some time to start working on the game, first on the tons of ideas and documentation, later on finding the right people to join in. I have an extensive IT (and nature-camping) background, and I've used all of that in this game.

Ivan - Our guru. Ivan works at a game development university (not as a janitor), he dreams code patterns and breathes out solutions for any kind of problems. He did the main code preparations and works on modular attachments like UI framework. And answers our questions, poor guy.

Slavko - Our junior. As every junior he had to do some boring tasks (yes, there are boring tasks even in game development), but he also did some of the features we are proud of, like structural integrity.

 

Known associates:

 

Emer - voicing and music

Prof Krunoslav - solving complex math calculations

Prof Hrvoje – proofreading, translation

Dobec - video editing, designer

Loha - photographer

For example, you'll be relevant to passing traders if you do a lot of trading. People in need will more often knock on your doo... hmm.. castle gate if you are famous for helping others.Not building a connection to the road won't spare you occasional visits by friendly bandits who just want your metal, or a trader running from the wolves. It'll just greatly reduce venturers coming from the road, and not all of the Kalnik creatures use roads to travel. Structural integrity (or gravity)To make building castles, villages and even landscapes even more satisfying, we have added gravity. Well, a kind of gravity, we call it a Structural integrity controller.Most importantly, it takes care of those blocks hanging in the air, once it was mined under it or a catapult destroyed some blocks when the projectile hit the wall. Those blocks are going to properly drop to the ground as Newton predicted.Don’t worry, your builders and miners know that and they’ll avoid such mistakes. And, if skilled enough, they will warn you about problems in building plans you are currently drawing.But also it’ll “use the force of gravity” on your buildings if you don’t have enough supporting walls for that glorious ceiling, or if you planned to build the entire castle on one pillar. I know, it’s easier to defend that way, but really...Every building material has a defined clinging force, so building your ceiling using only sand will just make your floors covered in sand and your (low skill) builders confused. BlueprintsDid it ever happen to you that you finish a nice and advanced north city wall, and then you realize you have to do the same thing three more times? Or you keep looking at the beauty of that tower and wishing you can easily build the same one, rotated, in several more places? Well, worry no more, Mighty Forests has blueprints.You can mark any 3D area and create blueprint of whatever blocks are built within. You can rotate the blueprint, mirror (left-right mirror, not upside-down so the roof goes down, but I'm willing to add that feature if you push me). You can share your blueprints between your games AND on the Forums via the in-game menu.Be aware though, I'll look at the best published blueprints and I WILL steal the best designs and show them to the bad guys, and teach them how to build them quickly and use them on your map against you. Tasks engine runs our worldOur Tasks engine is running the show in Mighty Forests. It took months to plan a good and easy-to-use concept, and then a few more to code this beauty. Once applied to a creature, it gives a total freedom in setting up settler jobs.The idea behind the engine was simple, we wanted an engine which could do this: I want 3 of my settlers to work on these two farmlands (Task 1). Once there is no more work on those farmlands , 2 of them should work on third farmland (Task 2), and the one left should continue working on manufacturing planks (Task 3). Once the logs run out of the selected input storage, he will haul more logs from other storages using a cart to bring more per trip done (Task 4). And once everything is done, they should equip swords and start training on some dummies(Task 5). And that we did. Each task can have input-specific input storage, output storage, workstation and workers. And each creature can have a sortable list of such tasks. And using a carefully planned UI, setting and reviewing tasks configuration is intuitive and fast.Some tasks are really simple, like “You go here”, but some tasks can have more advanced setup, like “this settler should craft 3 best quality iron swords (since he’s my best smith), he should take iron ingots from the closest storage, work on this lvl 3 smithy and store swords in this armoury once they are done” Skills and researchYou learn and research by workingWe want our armoursmiths to level up their armour-crafting skill while crafting armour. It's the way most of today’s games work. And that's great. But when it comes to research, even stone-age research, it's usually done by "scientists" standing in front of the table and discovering better ways to farm or better armour designs.It wasn't like that back then. There were no "scientists" in those villages and castles. There were hard working people who had good ideas. Who were not just working, they were also learning and experimenting and researching while working. Who is in a better position to discover or reproduce some advanced armour design than the person who actually spends days producing armours? In almost every task you can divide work-time between three areas: producing, learning and researching; with minimum of 5% in any area.How does that work? Let’s say a passing trader ordered a big shipment of advanced shields. But, you don’t even know how to produce such an advanced shield. So you set the armoursmith to mainly do research while crafting shields by setting research timeshare to a maximum. Once the armoursmith managed to reach the desired advancement, you switch from mainly research to mainly production, thus speeding up production, to quickly fulfill the order. Research treeIn order to keep it simple, we’ve organized all the research areas to have five levels, from primitive to the “most advanced technology in medieval ages”. Every tool, every armour and weapon can be crafted in five different quality variants, with the highest quality requiring additional gold and silver for crafting to make it truly legendary.We have also included the research for workstations upgrades, so you can research and build bigger, better (and more beautiful) smithies. Or farms, each upgrade level for farming brings something new, not just an increase in yield.Farms with an irrigation upgrade need to be weeded more often and they yield more, farms with a permaculture upgrade need less work and, as for some food cultures, they don’t require reseeding. FameWe are playing with the idea to add fame scores in the game, divided in few categories, like Innkeeping, Trading, Crafting, Military, Helpfulness.Yes, that would mean that you'll be able to receive guests, feed them and rent rooms. And they will spread the word about your hospitality and hopefully pay you for the service received. Or become a famous smith and take pride in the best axes for miles around.This won't be included in the first release, as we need to leave something for the future updates ;-).I would prefer to have a ( virtually ) bug-free game ready for Alpha 1 release, rather than trying to cover all the ideas we have. Game’s development stageCodewise, the game is ready for the basic/advanced play. All of the main features are done and tested. You can Build, Mine, Farm, Craft, Chop wood, Gather, Fish, Hunt, Haul, Tailor, Eat, Sleep, Train, Guard, Patrol, Follow, Protect, Fight (ranged and melee), Import/export building blueprints... and it all works well.What we lack is UI and models/animations. We have basic models with basic animations, most of which are attack animations. Right now we are using Attack slash animation for wood chopping, thrust animation for sawing and Dead animation for sleeping. That is why this is the area of the game that will get most attention during the next two months from our new 3D guy/girl (if the campaign succeeds), right after we finish implementing the UI. Ivan did a great job on UI framework, so it’s a piece of cake now to add buttons with all kinds of possibilities.We have already finished the first 20% of the UI and the framework is doing great, all of the features planned to be in UI are prototyped and working. Why crowdfunding?This Campaign isn't here to determine if this game will get developed or not. It will.I got a full written permission from my wife that I am allowed to develop this game full-time for another 6 months. Signed and verified by all the recognized authorities. And trust me (or ask Ivan), I can write loads of good code within that time period. And even some bad one too.We’ve created this campaign to:
Get some funds to hire 3D animator now, rather than later
See public reaction to the game, story, gameplay and game features
Create an active player community
And to set proper goals for investing time into the visual parts of the game, since it costs a lot of time to do it really nicely. I don't need Mighty Forests of Kalnik to look perfect, but I know some of you do, and I have nothing against that.What I want to accomplish with this game is to create an advanced intelligent game through smart and innovative features, which will really make you think and plan and adopt. Like Rimworld, or Factorio. Because that's the kind of game I want to play and develop. And some of the features presented here are actually really good features, aren't they? So, this is the deal I'm offering:- if Mighty Forests crowdfunding campaign fails, you'll get your money back, I'll invest 6 more months, full time, into the game, and start selling it soon through game site and probably Steam. That should be enough to convince my wife that I'm not completely crazy, I hope.- if we do collect the specified amount right now, we’ll hire a 3D animator straight away, the game will get developed faster and into a more beautiful world to jump in.- and if we collect 500,000, I'll found a proper primary school in my hometown, where my kids will learn how to think and not how to ... well, you know.And I'll develop the game like crazy, of course. Ivan and I each have 15+ years of development experience and have worked on number of large-scale applications. We cannot anticipate every problem that might arise, nobody can do that, but we know how to plan with future unknown problems in mind.We have enough funding for at least 6 more months even if we don't get a dime, and in that time 2 senior developers can create a miracle, especially when motivated like we are.So, as long as no huge fast-moving space rock hits our planet, we'll be good and Mighty Forests of Kalnik will become a full-release game. The TeamCore team:Karlo - That’s me. I started pondering on this idea for a game a few years ago. It took me some time to start working on the game, first on the tons of ideas and documentation, later on finding the right people to join in. I have an extensive IT (and nature-camping) background, and I've used all of that in this game.Ivan - Our guru. Ivan works at a game development university (not as a janitor), he dreams code patterns and breathes out solutions for any kind of problems. He did the main code preparations and works on modular attachments like UI framework. And answers our questions, poor guy.Slavko - Our junior. As every junior he had to do some boring tasks (yes, there are boring tasks even in game development), but he also did some of the features we are proud of, like structural integrity. Known associates: Emer - voicing and musicProf Krunoslav - solving complex math calculationsProf Hrvoje – proofreading, translationDobec - video editing, designerLoha - photographer

story:
Who We Are

Nitromsoft Entertainment Renaissance (or NER for short) is an indie development studio based in Prague, Czech Republic that focuses on topics that increases public awareness. Monopoly Monster is a PC/Mac based freeware game about ongoing negotiations on ACTA, SOPA and PIPA agreements and the battle behind it.


The Impact

The game delivers the message in an attractive and understandable way and makes the topic entertaining so we believe it has the potential to reach masses and teach them on the topic the way everyone enjoys.

The video is captured right from the game in its current state. There is some basic gameplay already and the technical aspect is pretty much done. It needs some polishing on the graphical side and some true and fun gameplay.


The Funding

We've been developing for several years, mostly on part-time basis. We've come up with several products, some of them commercial that covers part of the development of our freeware products.

IndieGoGo campaigning is our first trial to get money for the development another way and if it works well we're ready to stick to this method and develop freeware only products as we believe that digital informations should spread across the web freely. 


Spread The Word

We have some fan base but it's not large. The feedback, however, has been very positive on Monopoly Monster up to date. If you like the concept and the message we'll be more than happy to see you sharing it and spreading the word about the game and the whole matter. Cheers.

story:
About us: The studio

Vadrac Studios (væd-ræk) is a newly established game design studio that focuses on creating game projects based on the ideas and workmanship of the college students interested in being a part of its project development teams. The studio is currently based in the city of Mesa, Arizona and is recruiting a lot of its talent from Arizona State University (ASU) Polytechnic, though our current and potential team members are not limited to only that campus.

The studio was founded by Carlos Quinto, a business graduate of Arizona State University now currently enrolled in the university’s Graphic Information Technology major. In addition to being the studio’s founder, Carlos is also the first project director for the studio’s first game project which is currently in development. In addition to Mr. Quinto, the first development team is made up of ten students:

Zuzanna Czerny – Character concept artist and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Zuzanna is creating the majority of the concept work for playable and non-playable characters. Her artwork is used by our 3D modelers to create the character models which will be placed into a game. Additionally, Zuzanna's artwork will be featured as the official style for the first project's game-related products.

Andrew Johnson – Stage concept artist and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Andrew creates all of the environment concepts and layouts for play progression.

Jason Jones – Stage designer and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Jason utilizes vector and raster imaging software to create the environment tiles for the game.

Will Richards – Character creator, 3D modeler, animator, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Will utilizes 3D modeling software to mold and render the character models. He also animates the models he creates.

Hailee Wilson – Character creator, 3D modeler, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Hailee utilizes 3D modeling software to create character models, props, and various game objects.

Charlie Eberspacher – Game asset designer, 2D artist, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Charlie uses vector and raster imaging software to create splash screens, effects, menus, and various images for use in-game.

Brandon Greene-Hooks – Character designer, font artist, asset designer, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Brandon is a jack-of-all-trades for the team in that he utilizes 3D modeling, vector imaging, and raster imaging software to create various things for the game, from characters to letters. He also assists in digital content creation for our website and online social networks.

Jahaira Mancinas – Programmer, stage editor, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Jahaira will be compiling all of the art assets our team creates and place them into the game engine whilst programming all of the necessary functions of gameplay to create the actual playable product.

Ryan Duvall – Programmer, stage editor, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Alongside Jahaira, Ryan will also be placing art assets and programming gameplay functions to create the game.

Daviel Quinto – Music composer and a student of Glendale Community College. An excellent bassist and guitarist, Daviel will be composing and recording the soundtrack for game projects. Depending on the project, he'll also be recruiting talented musicians to aid in the recording process.

 

The studio also has a few students working behind the scenes on other projects to develop the studio:

Artemis Yanez – Web master, digital and print content creator, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Artemis works to develop the studio website and create assets we would use for all of our web spaces. Additionally, Artemis utilizes vector, raster, and print layout software to design various print projects, such as business cards and posters.

Dominique Hankins – 3D modeler, assistant web designer, digital content creator, and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Dominique assists Artemis with his various web projects utilizing vector and raster software to create and manage content. Dominique also provides 3D modeling work for both the development team and digital content.

Chris Salemi – Administrative assistant and a student of ASU Polytechnic. Chris helps on the the business side of things in assisting Mr. Quinto with project schedules, HR, and crowdfunding campaigns.

This initial campaign will be a way for the studio to pay for the business expenses it incurs for its founding and acquisition of software and supplies. We’re hoping this will be enough to cover what we need and finish the first game project by the end of summer 2013. At the conclusion of the game’s development, there will be actions taken to expand the studio and increase the number of projects to get more student development teams onboard. Within five years time, we’re looking to be financially self-sufficient to the point where we can work on more large-scale projects and have talented students hired on as full-time developers. By then, we’re hoping to be a go-to funnel for those looking to get into the gaming industry.

Where your money goes: The budget

For this campaign, the studio will need US $2,000 to cover initial expenses. Here’s an expenses run-down:

Unaccounted costs are possible costs we may incur from any other fees we have not currently incurred, a financial safety net, essentially. Development team support costs is a savings fund we would use to help pay for work amenities and other items to create a productive work space for the development team, such as ergonomic office chairs and keyboards. If this campaign does not manage to reach its initial goal, we’ll be prioritizing covering the expenses we have already incurred or we know will incur before diverting finances to anything else.

While we currently do not have any follow-up goals to reach during this campaign, any funds we obtain which surpass our goal will still go towards development team support. However, should our donations reach or exceed a total of US $12,000, we will take the excess funds to pay for an intern to join as a salaried developer for the current project. We would follow the same procedure for every team member for every US $10,000 over the goal we accumulate.

Donate and launch our future

While the studio’s goal is to become a competitive developer in the gaming industry, the focus of building our foundation will come from the talent and ideas of those budding designers looking to get into the industry. While the tools of today have made it easier to develop games, it still takes imagination, time, and dedication to make a great game, and we want to foster the creativity of our students and develop their abilities to start and finish a project and work as a team. This way, our interns come to an understanding of what goes on in the development cycle, gain insight into working on a development team, and be humbled by the hard work that goes into creating a great game. In addition to educational and working experience, student projects are released as buyable products so students receive real commercial feedback on their work.

Supporting us will open up doors for students to work their way into their careers, and you would also support a studio which will focus on setting a precedent of quality in what it takes to create games which surpass the realm of being solely entertainment.

Spread the word!

Currently, we’ve set up a Facebook page and a Youtube channel which will document updates on the project’s status. In addition, we’re developing a web page for the studio which will be posted on the campaign’s page after its completion. We’ll also be putting up a game document of the first project for the public to view on the campaign site as well. Exposure is just as valuable to us at this stage as actual donations, so spread the information to whoever you can, whether it be liking us on Facebook, Tweeting about us, or word of mouth amongst the people you know.

Look for us in the future as we plan on starting another campaign towards the end of the year to gain funds to purchase a space we can use as a work studio for all of our future projects.
